questions.info: A new antiplatelet agent is developed for the prevention of recurrence of stroke. In a large randomized clinical trial with equal numbers of men and women, the rates of stroke are lower in patients receiving the new agent than in patients receiving the standard treatment. Results are shown below.

infoImages.alt: Clinical trial results showing stroke rates

questions.stem: Which of the following is the primary site of the pathophysiologic process in this patient?
questions.explanation: Page 59 discusses MELAS. Mutations in MT-TL1 (Mitochondrially encoded tRNA leucine 1). A common mutation is A3243G. Can result in multiple mitochondrial deficiencies and associated disorders. It is associated with: Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy, Lactic acidosis, Stroke-like episodes (MELAS). MELAS is a rare mitochondrial disorder known to affect many parts of the body, especially the nervous system and the brain. Symptoms of MELAS include: Recurrent severe headaches, Muscle weakness (myopathy), Hearing loss, Stroke-like episodes with a loss of consciousness, seizures, and other problems affecting the nervous system.

questions.stem: A 32-year-old woman has had fecal incontinence since giving birth to her first child 1 year ago. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the fecal incontinence in this patient?

options.text: Achalasia of the internal anal sphincter
Increased pressure of the anal sphincter
Spastic contraction of the puborectalis muscle

questions.explanation:
UWORLD = 28yo woman, g1p0, goes into labor at 38 weeks gestation. During the second stage, as the patient is pushing, the fetus develops a non-reassuring fetal heart rate. A midline episiotomy is performed to expedite delivery. A vertical, midline incision is made at the posterior vaginal opening through the vaginal and subvaginal mucosa. Which structure is most likely involved in this incision?
 Perineal body. It is essential to the integrity of the pelvic floor and cut in a midline episiotomy. A midline episiotomy is a vertical incision from the posterior vaginal wall to the perineal body.

 AMBOSS explains that fecal incontinence is a common complication of 3rd degree perineal lacerations from the posterior vaginal wall to the external anal sphincter, and in severe cases possibly the internal anal sphincter. Injury to the pudendal nerve (S2-S4) is also related.

questions.stem: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department because of a swollen tender ankle. An x-ray of the ankle is strongly suggestive of osteosarcoma. She and her parents are told only that 'further evaluation is needed.' Which of the following next steps is most appropriate?

options.text: Request that an oncologist discuss the findings with them immediately
Request the presence of the hospital chaplain, then discuss the findings
Speak with the parents alone about the findings
Speak with the patient alone about the findings
Speak with the patient and her parents about the findings

questions.explanation: Physicians should always encourage healthy minor-guardian communication. Also you're going to do some serious things to cure this girl's disease, leading up to amputation. You can't hide that from her.

questions.stem: An otherwise healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of episodes of wheezing and shortness of breath while participating in track meets with her high school team. Her respirations are 12/min. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A diagnosis of exercise-induced asthma is made. Exposure to which of the following is most likely to precipitate a similar episode in this patient in the future?
questions.explanation: Page 744 PDF. This girl has exercise induced asthma. It is not well understood why it happens but the triggers are recognized. Normally when breathing occurs, the nasal passages and turbinates act to humidify/warm the air. During exercise, mouth breathing predominates, bypassing this warming/humidifying step. Cold, dry air is the strongest external trigger of exercise-induced asthma.

questions.stem: A study is conducted to assess the effect of a new screening test on the mortality rate of prostate cancer. Prior to implementation of screening, the overall 5-year survival rate was 70%. After initiating the screening in the randomly selected study population, the 5-year survival rate increases to 85%. During this time, there were no changes in the treatment of prostate cancer. The apparent decrease in mortality could be due to which of the following types of bias?
questions.explanation: Page 267. Lead-time bias occurs when earlier detection is mistaken for increased survival, but survival was not impacted at all and patients should be compared by looking at their disease severity.

questions.info: A new antiplatelet agent is developed for the prevention of recurrence of stroke. In a large randomized clinical trial with equal numbers of men and women, the rates of stroke are lower in patients receiving the new agent than in patients receiving the standard treatment. Results are shown below.

infoImages.alt: Clinical trial results showing stroke rates

questions.stem: Which of the following is the primary site of the pathophysiologic process in this patient?
questions.explanation: Absolute risk: the difference in risk (not the proportion) attributable to the intervention as compared to a control. (.12) - (.04) = .08ARR = 8%.

questions.stem: A previously healthy 32-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of severe epigastric pain, nausea, and vomiting blood. Her temperature is 37Â°C (98.6Â°F), pulse is 125/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 85/45 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool skin and a tender abdomen. A decrease in which of the following hemodynamic parameters is the most likely cause of this patient's hypotension?
questions.explanation:
Vomiting blood and cool skin indicates this is a type of hypovolemic shock. To understand shock, remember that;

BP = TPR x COââ2) CO = SV x HRââ3) SV = EDV - ESV

In hypovolemic shock, you are losing fluid, so stroke volume is decreased and end diastolic volume is decreased.
Decreased EDV means that the "filling volume" is decreased, which also means the preload will be decreased.
Also, skin is cool because you're decreasing SV â decreased CO â Ang II/ADH/etc is released to vasoconstrict increasing resistance.
Since there is increased resistance, there is less blood flow causing skin to be cold/clammy.

BP = TPR x ((EDV - ESV) x HR)

questions.stem: A 31-year-old man has a large, yellow, soft mass deeply infiltrating the gluteus maximus muscle. Microscopic examination of the excised mass shows irregular vacuolated cells and clear cells with frequent mitoses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Lipomas/Liposarcomas are the most common soft tissue fat tumors. Benign tumors are usually well-differentiated and well-demarcated, with low mitotic activity, no metastases, and no necrosis.
Malignant tumors (cancers) may show poor differentiation, erratic growth, local invasion, metastasis, and apoptosis. High mitotic activity.
Fat tumors:
Lipoma: benign, low mitotic activity
Liposarcoma: malignant, increased mitotic activity

questions.stem: A 25-year-old woman has a flu-like illness (fever, myalgias, fatigue) that is followed by decreased exercise tolerance and shortness of breath, particularly when lying down. Findings on examination of tissue obtained on myocardial biopsy are suggestive of a viral infection. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her illness?
questions.explanation: This patient has symptoms of viral myocarditis, which is most commonly caused by Coxsackie, a picornavirus.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old boy with mild mental retardation is brought to the physician by his parents because of a 2-week history of frequent staring spells. Examination of the skin shows pale oval-shaped areas on the trunk. A CT scan of the head without contrast shows multiple calcified subependymal and cortical lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Tuberous sclerosis has HAMARTOMAS, Angiofibromas, Mitral regurgitation, Ash leaf spots, Rhabdomyomas, tuberous sclerosis, Officially dominant, mental retardation, agiomyolipomas, and seizures.
TS is known to have more subependymal astrocytomas and ungual fibromas in the nails.

questions.stem: A patient is found to have increased hemoglobin concentration and hematocrit. Arterial oxygen saturation is decreased, and erythropoietin concentration is increased. Which of the following is the most likely explanation?
questions.explanation:
This is reactive/appropriate polycythemia vera, which is due to high altitude or lung disease. SaO2 is low, and EPO is increased.
Another way to approach the question is looking at the blood smear. It's pretty normal (no megakaryocytes, no increased number of platelets, no rods, nothing blue, etc). A blood smear from a COPD patient will be normal. Just an increased number of RBCs due to the increased EPO leading to increased Hgb.
Myelofibrosis â also called agnogenic myeloid metaplasia (AMM), myelosclerosis, chronic idiopathic myelofibrosis, idiopathic myelofibrosis, and myelosclerosis with myeloid metaplasia â is a form of cancer that arises in the bone marrow.

questions.stem: At a postnatal checkup, a 6-week-old female newborn weighs 20 ounces less than at delivery. Her mother says she vomits and regurgitates bile-tinged fluid after every feeding. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this abnormality?
questions.explanation: Annular pancreas is the only answer that accounts for the bile in the vomit; of the choices, it is the only obstruction distal to the 2nd part of the duodenum, where the bile enters the GIT. Meckel diverticulum would require more for the diagnosis, such as ectopic gastric tissue, hematochezia, or RLQ pain.

questions.stem: A 55-year-old man comes to the physician because of constipation since starting an over-the-counter medication 2 weeks ago for a chronic, persistent cough and sinus congestion. Which of the following ingredients in this medication is the most likely cause of this patient's new symptom?
questions.explanation: Dextromethorphan is an opium alkaloid derivative. Dextromethorphan is a drug of abuse. The main risks associated with dextromethorphan are ataxia, central nervous system (CNS) stimulation, dizziness, lethargy and psychotic behavior. Less frequently with large doses seizures and respiratory depression can occur. Nausea, vomiting, constipation and tachycardia may also occur. (toxnet.nlm.nih.gov).

questions.stem: A 19-year-old man who is a college student is brought to the emergency department because of the sudden onset of right-sided chest pain and difficulty breathing after an accident in which he was thrown from his bicycle. He has difficulty walking and cannot climb stairs because of pain and shortness of breath. He is slightly cyanotic, afebrile, and tachypneic. Which of the following is most suggestive that fractured ribs caused the respiratory problem?
questions.explanation:
Bronchophony = pneumonia
Expiratory stridor = tracheobronchial obstruction (mass/foreign body)
Inspiratory stridor = laryngeal obstruction
Succussion splash = test for pyloric stenosis
When there is a fractured rib it will cause a trauma pneumothorax which can cause air to escape and become trapped under the skin leading to crepitus

questions.stem: A 66-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after sustaining injuries in a motor vehicle collision. He is pronounced dead on arrival. A photograph of the left kidney and a photomicrograph of a section of the distal left ureter taken at autopsy are shown. Examination of the right kidney and ureter shows no abnormalities. Which of the following was the most likely predisposing factor in the development of the ureteral lesion in this patient?
questions.explanation:
It's transitional cell carcinoma, which smoking is a common risk factor for; it can involve the renal pelvis/calyces. The histology shows the papillary nature of the tumor, but it can also be flat or nodular according to Pathoma.
Also known as urothelial carcinoma. Most common tumor of urinary tract system (can occur in renal calyces, renal pelvis, ureters, and bladder). Can be suggested by painless hematuria (no casts).
Arylamine is an amine. Aromatic amines are related to the textile industry and cigarette smoke and can also lead to transitional cell carcinoma, but there is no indication to pick arylamine exposure over cigarette smoking.
Vinyl chloride is related to PVC pipes and affects the liver of plumbers, leading to angiosarcoma.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother after the dentist found many unerupted and supernumerary teeth. Physical examination shows frontal bossing, hypertelorism, and retained deciduous teeth. The patient can place her shoulders together anteriorly. Serum studies show decreased alkaline phosphatase activity. A chest x-ray shows hypoplasia of the clavicles. Skull x-rays show open sutures and multiple Wormian bones. Genetic testing shows a mutation in the CBFA1 gene. Which of the following cell types is directly affected by the mutation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
A big thing here too is noticing that the ALP is decreased. Osteoblast activity is measured by bone ALP. I think that was the main focus here and not that you necessarily need to know the CBFA1 gene mutation.
This is a conditional called craniocleidodysplasia. The kid on Stranger Things with the lisp has the disorder. No collar bones, too many teeth, frontal bossing => craniocleidodysplasia. CBFA1 is a gene highly implicated in osteoblast function.
Dustin, or Gaten Matarazzo from Stranger Things = https://www.huffpost.com/entry/gaten-matarazzo-dustin-stranger-things-speaks-about-disability_n_57eadeb1e4b024a52d2b53b9
Also relevant = https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wormian_bones which are intrasutural bones, extra bone pieces within a suture.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old woman is transferred to a rehabilitative service 2 days after operative repair of a fracture of the right femur. She weighs 65 kg (143 lb). Findings on physical and mental status examinations are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most important predictor of success in the rehabilitation of this patient?
questions.explanation:
This is indirectly asking about peak bone density. That whole thing about weight-bearing exercises, eating right, yada yada, before and during that down-slope phase of life for bone density. All about reducing that 1% per year age-related bone density loss as best as we can. Level of activity is precisely like weight-bearing exercise. (Consider: no activity, bed-ridden -- say goodbye to your bones; highly active, runs every other day -- good amount of weight-bearing / stress to induce remodeling and maintain integrity of the bones.)
Someone did make a good point saying -- "sympathetikey Yeah, I was thinking about that while taking the exam. Just got thrown off because I don't see how that matters, now that they've fractured the femur. How do prior increases in bone density allow for better chances of bone healing?" and unfortunately thats the nature of these questions. Cant do anything about age. Calcium and Vitamin D are relevant but activity level is most significant.

questions.stem: A physician prescribes a newly marketed drug to 45 patients. Over the next several weeks, she notes that the drug has good therapeutic efficacy, but it increased serum liver enzyme activities three times the normal value in 5 of the 45 patients. The physician cannot find any official data linking the new drug with liver dysfunction. Which of the following is the most appropriate action by the physician?

options.text: Continue the drug in all patients but inform the drug company about the association
Discontinue the drug in all patients but study the results again to identify other possible causes of the abnormal findings
Discontinue the new drug in affected patients and file MedWatch reports on the FDA's Web site
Discontinue the new drug in all patients and take no further action
Do nothing, since the drug company most likely previously conducted all necessary research

questions.explanation:
https://www.fda.gov/safety/medwatch-fda-safety-information-and-adverse-event-reporting-program
When a trial drug comes in, you must report any weird side effects and discontinue the drug in those experiencing it. However, by this point the drug has already gone through clinical trials and should be fine in the remaining 40 patients, but we will still be monitoring them too.
The point of this is to find any adverse effects that were not found before.

questions.stem: A sedentary 50-year-old man with hypertension comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of depression, anxiety, difficulty sleeping, fatigue, decreased appetite, and poor memory and concentration. He had an anterior wall myocardial infarction 3 months ago. He has one glass of wine each evening. He is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 67 kg (148 lb); BMI is 25 kg/mÂ². His pulse is 104/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 177/89 mm Hg. ECG is unchanged. Labs show hemoglobin 13.8 g/dL, LDL cholesterol 127 mg/dL, serum LDL cholesterol 117 mg/dL. Which of the following is most likely to decrease this patient's risk for mortality over the next 2 years?

options.text: Diet high in omega-3 fatty acids

questions.explanation:
Most of the pts values were normal. Drinking wasn't outrageous, LDL was mild, BMI has fine. He did have HTN though.
The biggest risk factors are the fact that he had suffered an MI and started suffering severe depression (weight loss/anxiety). Thus, he is more at risk for suicide.

questions.stem: A 23-year-old woman has had fever, hypotension, and disseminated intravascular coagulation for 24 hours. She has a history of splenectomy following trauma. Which of the following bacteria is the most likely cause of this overwhelming sepsis?
questions.explanation:
Encapsulated organisms run rampant in patients who have no spleen, whether physically or functionally. (Recall the wide-array of sequalae sickle cell patients experience thanks to their functional autosplenectomy.)
E coli and Pseudomonas are also encapsulated. And if this woman had a splenectomy, she was probably vaccinated against the encapsulated bugs so this question is pretty much bullshit. Under strep pneumo they talk about how this causes sepsis in asplenic patients. But the test writer fucked up if this question was just a basics question on Strep pneumo.

questions.stem: A 44-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination after two separate Pap smears showed atypical squamous cells of undetermined significance. Results of a molecular diagnostic test show the presence of the viral E6 protein of human papillomavirus. This protein is known to promote cell growth and malignancy by causing cellular p53 protein degradation. This degradation most likely begins when the p53 protein is targeted to which of the following types of cellular enzymes?
questions.explanation:
In eukaryotic cells, two major pathwaysâthe ubiquitin-proteasome pathway and lysosomal proteolysisâmediate protein degradation.
The major pathway of selective protein degradation in eukaryotic cells uses ubiquitin as a marker that targets cytosolic and nuclear proteins for rapid proteolysis.
The other major pathway of protein degradation in eukaryotic cells involves the uptake of proteins by lysosomes and digestion by proteases.
"Certain viruses have evolved to recruit the cellular E3 ligases to induce the degradation of cellular proteins that might have harmful effects on the viral life cycle. For instance, the protein E6 of Human papillomavirus (HPV) recruits the cellular E3 ubiquitin ligase E6-AP to induce ubiquitination and degradation of p53, thereby allowing viral replication." from: https://www.mdpi.com/1999-4915/9/11/322/htm
BORTEZOMIB

questions.stem: A 43-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 10 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for an initial prenatal visit. Physical examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 10-week gestation. This patient is at increased risk for a child with Down syndrome if she has which of the following sets of ultrasound and serum findings?
questions.explanation:
Down Syndrome Labs: High HI, hCG and Inhibin.

Increased nuchal translucency
Increased hCG
Increased inhibin
Decreased AFP
Decreased PAPPA (pregnancy associated plasma protein A)

questions.stem: A 36-year-old woman comes to the office because of a 1-month history of joint pain, frequent headaches, and fatigue. Her temperature is 37.6 Â°C (99.6 Â°F). Physical examination shows edema of the upper and lower extremities. An abdominal CT scan is shown. Which of the following additional findings was most likely seen in this patient?
questions.explanation: This patient has Felty syndrome, an extraarticular manifestation of RA. Symptoms include a triad of RA, splenomegaly and neutropenia.

questions.stem: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of fever, malaise, and a rash. She had a single painless lesion on her labia 3 weeks ago, but it resolved spontaneously. She is sexually active, but she and her partner do not use condoms consistently. Her temperature is 38Â°C (100.4Â°F). Physical examination shows a diffuse erythematous rash that includes the palms and soles. A sensitive but nonspecific rapid serologic screening test that uses which of the following reagents is most likely to support a diagnosis?

options.text: Live Treponema pallidum on glass slides

questions.explanation:
Palms and soles rashe is seen in CARS, Coxsackie A, Rickettsia, and Syphilis.
She gas syphillis which can be tested for with VDRL/RPR or more specifically with FTA-ABS.

This question wants the sensitive but nonspecific rapid RPR. RPR and VDRL both test for antibodies against cardiolipin, while FTA tests for anitbodies against syphilis antigens (and this test remains positive for life since anti-treponemal therapy wont get rid of the antigens).

The cardiolipin can be a false positive with pregnancy, lupus, and many other things.

questions.stem: An 80-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the physician because of a 2-month history of severe constipation. Use of over-the-counter laxatives has not relieved his symptoms. Abdominal examination shows distention. Colonoscopy shows no abnormalities. This patient most likely has dysfunction of which of the following nerves?
questions.explanation:
Fecal incontinence is usually related to the pudendal nerve (S2-S4) so many people might pick E, but eating and digesting are not sympathetic activities. Passing feces requires parasympathetic innervation. The GIT chapter discusses that the hindgut parasympathetics are from the pelvic splanchnic innervation. The foregut and midgut get vagal parasympathetic innervation.

The hypogastric nerve is for sympathetic stimulation of emission during sex. The pudendal nerve also has a part here and helps with expulsion. The pudendal nerve is also important for the external anal sphincter and damage can lead to fecal incontinence.

questions.stem: Following a wedding reception attended by 75 people, 25 adults develop low-grade fever, abdominal cramping, vomiting, and diarrhea. The symptoms begin 24 to 36 hours after the event and resolve without treatment in 3 to 4 days. Studies of stool specimens show no occult blood, no leukocytes, and cultures grow no pathogens. Several family members exhibit similar symptoms 3 days after the initial outbreak. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.explanation:
The speed of onset (24-36 hours), lack of blood, lack of pathogens, and self resolving nature all depict that this is a viral gastroenteritis. The norovirus is a positive RNA calicivirus that causes outbreaks commonly on cruises, leading to watery diarrhea. It is mainly transmitted via shellfish and can have concomitant HepA infection. Its incubation can take 1-2 days and self-resolves!

Rotavirus is a dsRNA reoviridae that causes infantile gastroenteritis but most people are vaccinated. Staph aureus is related to nonbloody food poisoning within 2-6 hours from preformed toxin. The others can cause blood. And bacteria would show up as pathogens.

questions.info: An investigator compares the DNA sequences of newborns with achondroplasia with the sequences of healthy newborns. DNA sequence analysis shows a GâC mutation in the fibroblast growth factor 3 (FGFR3) gene on chromosome 4. The sequences are shown below.

infoImages.alt: DNA sequence comparison showing achondroplasia mutation

questions.stem: As a result of this mutation, an MspI restriction enzyme site is created. Which of the following sequences most likely represents the substrate specificity of MspI?
questions.explanation: Most restriction enzymes bind palindromes and 5'CCGG or 3'GGCC would both be acceptable answers here to bind to the underlined segment.

questions.stem: A female newborn delivered at 36 weeks' gestation is in respiratory distress. Apgar scores are 3 and 5 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Physical examination shows cyanosis. Endotracheal and nasogastric tubes are placed. The x-ray shown depicts the nasogastric tube in the left hemithorax, displacement of the mediastinum to the right, and absence of bowel gas in the abdomen. This condition most likely results from which of the following embryologic events?
questions.explanation: This patient has a congenital diaphragmatic hernia, causing abdominal contents to pop up in the left thorax, since the right is safe thanks to the liver. The lungs get compressed leading to hypoplasia. This is due to D and can also be due to trauma. Choices A and B are embryology related. The myotome is divided into 2 sections, the epimere and hypomere, which form the epaxial and hypaxial muscles. The epaxial muscles are the erector spinae and small intervertebral muscles, while the hypaxial muscles are everything else including those of the limbs, innervated by ventral rami.

questions.stem: An 82-year-old woman is brought to the physician because of a 1-week history of episodes of light-headedness and fainting. She has hypertension currently treated with propranolol. Her pulse is 45/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. An ECG shows normal, regular P waves followed by normal QRS complexes. The physician decreases the dose of propranolol. Five days later, the patient's pulse is 80/min, and her symptoms have resolved. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's low pulse while taking the higher dose of propranolol?

options.text: Decreased activation of fast sodium channels
Increased calcium influx during late phase of slow depolarization
Increased potassium influx during rapid depolarization phase
Increased sodium efflux during early repolarization phase

questions.explanation: BBs work by decreasing cAMP and Ca2+ thereby slowing SAN & AVN activity. This prolongs phase 4 of depolarization. Therefore, they are known to increase the duration of diastole (predominantly) causing both a rise in heart coronary perfusion and reduction in heart rate.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of pain in his jaw and left arm. He also has had intense thirst and increased urination during this period. He was found to have peptic ulcer disease 2 months ago. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a calcium concentration of 13.5 mg/dL and an intact parathyroid hormone concentration of 110 pg/mL (N=10â65). An x-ray of the left humerus shows no abnormalities. Which of the following biologic mechanisms best explains the impaired calcium homeostasis in this patient?

options.text: Decreased calcium reabsorption by renal tubules
Decreased expression of parathyroid hormone receptors on osteoblasts
Decreased hydroxylation of vitamin D by renal tubule epithelial cells
Increased calcitonin secretion by thyroid gland
Increased motility of monocytes in bone marrow

questions.explanation: This patient has primary hyperparathyroidism caused by parathyroid adenoma. Addition of the peptic ulcer suggest Zollinger ---> MEN1 but none of that is important because that's not what they are asking. All they are asking for is the function of PTH. PTH promotes osteoclast activity of breaking bone hydroxyapatite into calcium and phosphate. But osteoclasts do not have a PTH receptor. PTH binds osteoblasts, which then secrete RANK-L to bind RANK receptors of osteoclasts and activate them.

questions.info: An 18-year-old woman comes to the physician because she has never had a menstrual period. Physical examination shows a 1-cm invagination where the vagina would normally be present. No uterus is palpable on rectal examination. Laboratory studies of serum show: Follicle-stimulating hormone 8.3 mIU/mL, Luteinizing hormone 6.7 mIU/mL, Estradiol 200 pg/mL (N=30â400), Testosterone 3 nmol/L (Nâ¤3.5).

infoImages.alt: Hormone levels in primary amenorrhea with absent uterus

questions.stem: Which of the following structures is most likely normal in this patient?
questions.explanation: The mullerian paramesonephric duct becomes the female internal structures; fallopian tubes, uterus, and upper vagina (lower portion comes from the urogenital sinus). Mayer Rokitansky Kuster Hauser syndrome presents with primary amenorrhea due to the lack of a uterus in females with full secondary sexual characteristics thanks to functional ovaries. This is often compared to Androgen insensitivity where the LH and testosterone will be high due to a lack of negative feedback, and the patient will have no pubic hair. So a 46, XY male will appear as a female with female external genitalia, a rudimentary vagina, but no uterus or fallopian tubes. These patients will have normal functioning testes in the labia majora, and they must surgically remove it in case of malignancy. AIS is an X-linked defect.

questions.stem: A 27-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of intermittent headaches and palpitations. Her initial blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg while she sits in a chair. When asked to sit on the examination table, she has facial flushing, and her blood pressure increases to 185/115 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This is a very unorthodox question scenario. But, the other choices do not fit in at all. Coarctation of the aorta (pg 317) would have a brachial femoral delay with increased risk of berry aneurysms, both due to increased blood flow to the head. Hyperthyroidism does not cause this, neither does aldosteronism. Renovascular HTN would just have HTN. This patient has a normal BP initially because pheos have a relapsing pattern. When people stand up, a lot of sympathetics fire off to prevent orthostatic hypotension, but in pheo she probably released too many catecholamines in her moment of standing.

questions.stem: Purified serum antibodies elicited by immunization with protein X are adsorbed to microtiter wells. The graph shows the amount of radiolabeled protein X that is bound by the solid-phase anti-X antibodies in the presence of varying concentrations of protein Y. With respect to the anti-X serum, which of the following interpretations regarding the epitopes expressed by proteins X and Y is correct?

image.alt: Competitive binding assay graph of protein X and protein Y

options.text: Proteins X and Y express the same epitopes
Proteins X and Y have no epitopes in common
Protein X expresses all of the epitopes expressed by protein Y, but protein Y does not express all of the epitopes expressed by protein X
Protein Y expresses all of the epitopes expressed by protein X, but protein X does not express all of the epitopes expressed by protein Y

questions.stem: A patient with a 1-week history of diarrhea has reduced tissue turgor. Arterial pH is 7.3; serum bicarbonate concentration is 15 mEq/L. This patient is also likely to have which of the following?

options.text: Increased circulating level of atrial natriuretic peptide

questions.explanation: This patient has a low pH and low HCO3. The chronic diarrhea will be compensated by respiratory hyperventilation leading to decreased CO2. Adrenal insufficiency (low aldosterone) has low Na HCO3, leading to metabolic acidosis. The HCO3/Cl exchanger increases Cl in exchange for HCO3, and K and H will be high. High NaHCO3 and low HkCl.

questions.info: A 28-year-old man has excessive thirst and polyuria. The following laboratory data are obtained: Baseline serum osmolality is 310 mOsm/kg, urine osmolality is 175 mOsm/kg. With 12 h water deprivation, urine osmolality is 185 mOsm/kg. With ADH (vasopressin) after water deprivation, urine osmolality increases to 315 mOsm/kg.

infoImages.alt: Serum and urine osmolality chart with ADH response

questions.stem: Which of the following is the primary site of the pathophysiologic process in this patient?
questions.explanation: Giving ADH increased urine osmolality. This means ADH is not being made but the kidney responds to ADH fine. The baseline urine osmolality is low (peeing a lot of water) so the patient is thirsty. When water is deprived, nothing changes significantly (so its not psychogenic polydipsia where the serum osmolality would normalize because their ADH works fine). ADH is synthesized in the supraoptic nucleus of the hypothalamus.

questions.info: A 38-year-old African American man with recently diagnosed hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. At his last visit 1 month ago, the patient agreed to initiate a regimen including increased physical activity, a low-sodium diet, and pharmacotherapy. He has had no weight loss since then. He is 175 cm (5 ft 9 in) tall and weighs 82 kg (180 lb); BMI is 27 kg/mÂ². His blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities.
questions.stem: Which of the following best describes the role of ethnicity when the appropriate medication is selected for this patient?

options.text: It should not play a role because cost, patient adherence, and adverse effects are of primary importance
It should not play a role because use of ethnicity could lead to stereotyping
It should not play a role because the variability of response to medications within a single ethnic group is greater than the different responses among ethnicities
It should play a role because the adverse effect profiles differ by ethnicity
It should play a role because the efficacy of certain classes of medications varies among different ethnicities

questions.explanation: According to UTD, it is said that for the young patient, ACEI, ARB, beta-blocker are of better efficacy for primary hypertension as a monotherapy, however, CCB and thiazide are better for the elderly and the black patients. "only pharmacokinetic processes which are biologically or biochemically mediated have the potential to exhibit differences between racial or ethnic groups. Thus, the pharmacokinetic factors which can be expected to potentially exhibit racial differences are (1) bioavailability for drugs which undergo gut or hepatic first-pass metabolism, (2) protein binding, (3) volume of distribution, (4) hepatic metabolism, and (5) renal tubular secretion. Absorption (unless active), filtration at the glomerulus, and passive tubular reabsorption would not be expected to exhibit racial differences."

questions.stem: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician to discuss donating a kidney to his 39-year-old sister who has type 1 diabetes mellitus and chronic renal failure. He has no history of major medical illness, and physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following best describes the likelihood that this donor's human leukocyte antigen type will match that of his sister?
questions.explanation: Two siblings have a 25% chance of being genotypically HLA identical, a 50% chance of being HLA haploidentical (sharing one haplotype), and a 25% chance that they share no HLA haplotypes. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2628004/

questions.stem: A male newborn is found to have a decreased blood thyroxine (T4) concentration on newborn screening. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show decreased concentrations of triiodothyronine (T3) and T4. His serum free T4 and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) concentrations are within the reference ranges. Which of the following best explains these findings?

options.text: Organification defect in T3 and T4 synthesis

questions.explanation: A low total but high free T4 indicates a loss of thyroid binding globulin. Bound T3/T4 is inactive and you can have high TBG in pregnancy and OCP use, since estrogen increases TBG. Alternatively, hepatic failure, steroid use, and nephrotic syndrome decreases TBG. "Thyroxine-binding globulin deficiency â Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) deficiency is characterized by low serum total T4 but normal free T4 and TSH; the diagnosis is confirmed by measuring TBG concentrations. These infants have normal thyroid function and do not require treatment." - uptodate

questions.stem: A 29-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of fever, muscle aches, sore throat, and nonproductive cough. His temperature is 38.9Â°C (102Â°F). Rhonchi are heard on auscultation of the chest. A chest x-ray shows bronchopneumonia of the right lower lobe. Symptoms persist after 7 days of amoxicillin therapy. A test result for cold agglutinins is positive. Which of the following features of the causal organism best explains the ineffectiveness of the pharmacotherapy in this patient?

options.text: Production of a Î²-lactamase that inactivates amoxicillin

questions.explanation: Mycoplasma pneumoniae. Cold IgM agglutinins. No response to amoxicillin due to the lack of a pepitidoglycan cell wall. Classic cause of atypical "walking" pneumonia (insidious onset, headache, nonproductive cough, patchy or diffuse interstitial infiltrate). X-ray looks worse than patient. High titer of cold agglutinins (IgM), which can agglutinate or lyse RBCs. Grown on Eaton agar. Treatment: macrolides, doxycycline, or fluoroquinolone (penicillin ineffective since Mycoplasma have no cell wall). ABC = Africa, Blindness, Chronic infection. DâK = everything else. Neonatal disease can be acquired during passage through infected birth canal. No cell wall. Not seen on Gram stain. Pleomorphic A. Bacterial membrane contains sterols for stability. Mycoplasmal pneumonia is more common in patients < 30 years old. Frequent outbreaks in military recruits and prisons. Mycoplasma gets cold without a coat (cell wall).

questions.stem: A 70-year-old man has a 3-month history of weakness and a 10-kg (22-lb) weight loss. He has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 50 years. An x-ray of the chest shows a 4-cm lesion in the right upper lobe. Serum calcium concentration is 13.5 mg/dL. There are no bone metastases. A malignant lesion arising in a segmental bronchus is seen during lobectomy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: He has a characteristic lesion of SqCC and the PTHrP is causing hypercalcemia. This cancer histologically presents with keratin pearls and intercellular bridges, and is often related to cavitation and cigarettes. It is also found centrally. Small cell carcinoma can actually produce ACTH, cause SIADH, or cause Lambert Eaton via antibodies against Ca channels. These show neuroendocrine findings of chromogranin A, NSE, synaptophysin, and NCAM/CD56.

questions.stem: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his neighbor because of a 3-week history of severe weakness and fatigue; he also has had a 7.3-kg (16-lb) weight loss during this period. He lives alone, and he says that his daughter usually visits him once or twice weekly to bring him groceries. However, he has eaten nothing but small quantities of saltine crackers and black coffee since his daughter left for vacation 1 month ago. He is 173 cm (5 ft 8 in) tall and now weighs 56 kg (124 lb); BMI is 19 kg/m^2. His pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 108/76 mm Hg. Physical examination shows generalized muscle weakness. Serum studies in this patient are most likely to show an increased concentration of which of the following hormones?
questions.explanation: This patient is in a period of stress. Cortisol's is a hormone necessary for life because it helps manage such situations. He is not eating enough and cortisol functions in maintaining his BP as well as keeping him alive via gluconeogenesis, lipolysis, and proteolysis to replenish what hes not eating

questions.stem: An 18-year-old boy has just been diagnosed with schizophrenia. His identical twin brother is unaffected, but he and his parents are concerned about his likelihood of developing the disorder. Which of the following best represents the brother's risk for developing schizophrenia?
questions.explanation: While the lifetime risk in the general population is just below 1%, it is 6.5% in first-degree relatives of patients and it rises to more than 40% in monozygotic twins of affected people. Analyzing classic studies of the genetics of schizophrenia done as early as in 1930s, Fischer concludes that a concordance rate for psychosis of about 50% in monozygotic twins seems to be a realistic estimate, which is significantly higher than that in dizygotic twins of about 10â19%. (ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4623659/#ref3)

questions.stem: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician 8 hours after the onset of severe pain of his low back that radiates down his left leg. He started a weight-lifting regimen earlier in the day during which he tried to lift a bar loaded with 91 kg (200 lb) from the ground to over his head. The pain began almost immediately after this attempt. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's pain?

options.text: A fracture of a lumbar vertebra
A tear in the sciatic nerve
A torn muscle in the low back

questions.explanation: Common knowledge amongst my family has always been "lifting heavy weights will cause a disc herniation." So I just thought of that. But in all reality, the other answer choices can be removed. He probably has a disc herniation at L5-S1, causing sciatica. He cannot have a lumbar fracture because he is young and there is no indication for a weak lumbar area in him. The deltoid rupture would not cause back pain. The sciatic nerve is very thick and will not "tear" but it is being compressed here due to the herniation. A torn muscle in the lower back would not have back pain.

questions.stem: A 25-year-old woman comes to the physician 2 days after noticing a mass in her right axilla. She also has a 1-week history of malaise, headaches, and night sweats. The patient says that she recently adopted a kitten and has sustained several bite and scratch marks. Her temperature is 37.8Â°C (100Â°F). Physical examination shows edema and tenderness of the right axillary lymph node. The skin over the node is erythematous, tough, and warm. There are scratches and bite marks of various ages over the upper extremities and hands. The result of an indirect fluorescent antibody test for Bartonella henselae is positive. A biopsy specimen of this lymph node is most likely to show which of the following histologic patterns?

options.text: Large activated lymphocytes with occasional plasma cells
Serous inflammation with abundant intravascular fibrin and few inflammatory cells

questions.explanation:
Cat scratch disease (Bartonella infection in immunocompetent hosts) causes lymphadenitis (especially in the axillary region) characterized by sarcoid-like non-caseating granulomas filled with neutrophils.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cat-scratch_disease
https://www.researchgate.net/figure/Typical-stellate-microabscess-of-cat-scratch-disease-A-Small-necrotizing-granulomas_fig1_51750307

questions.stem: A 65-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of substernal chest pain, nausea, and sweating for 1 hour. He has a 10-year history of type 2 diabetes mellitus and hypertension. His pulse is 120/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 98/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a jugular venous distention of 12 cm. Crackles are heard halfway up the lung fields posteriorly. Which of the following ECG findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This man is showing symptoms of an MI.

Initial phase of myocardial infarction leads to subendocardial necrosis involving < 50% of the myocardial thickness (subendocardial infarction); EKG shows ST-segment depression.

Continued or severe ischemia (>20 minutes) leads to transmural necrosis involving most of the myocardial wall (transmural infarction); EKG shows ST-segment elevation.

The PR segment is usually isoelectric. A depression or elevation should evoke the diagnosis of acute pericarditis or atrial infarction.
QT interval (ventricular depolarization and repolarization) prolongation can be due to drugs and predisposes to torsades.
Short QT syndrome is an autosomal dominant disorder of the electrical system and can lead to SCD if not treated with an ICD.

questions.stem: Three elderly residents of an assisted living facility in rural Pennsylvania are admitted to the hospital within 3 days of one another because of pneumonia. All three patients have a history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and returned home from a weekend retreat at a residence hall 4 to 7 days ago. Forty-three other individuals attended the retreat. Two other attendees developed pneumonia shortly after returning home, but they did not require hospital admission; they were a 37-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus treated with corticosteroids and a 46-year-old man with severe asthma. No other retreat attendees, including nine children under the age of 5 years, developed a respiratory illness. None of the other residents of the assisted living facility have any symptoms of respiratory illness. Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Legionnaires is an atypical pneumonia commonly seen in smokers and COPD patients. In this question only the immunocompromised and elderly were affected.

Adenovirus would make all the kids sick and also cause conjunctivitis and diarrhea and much more.
Influenza would also make many people sick and hospitalize them.
RSV really just causes pneumonia in infants.
Strep pneumoniae would also infect many other people not just the older and immunocompromised.

questions.stem: A 56-year-old woman has frequently burned herself while cooking over the past several months. Examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation in both upper extremities and in a portion of her trunk from the clavicles to just below the nipples. Touch, vibratory sensation, and proprioception are normal. There is some wasting of the small muscles of her hands. Which of the following findings is most likely on MRI of the head and spine?

options.text: Dilated third ventricle causing damage to both sides of the thalamus
Edema in the postcentral gyri on both sides secondary to multiple strokes
Sclerotic plaques bilaterally in the anterolateral white matter of the spinal cord
Syrinx of the central region of the spinal cord from C-4 to T-5
Tumors compressing the lateral funiculi of the spinal cord at C-4

questions.explanation: She has the classic presentation often seen in questions.

questions.stem: Which of the following changes in the cardiovascular system occurs with normal aging?

A 28-year-old woman of Eastern European Jewish decent comes to the office 2 days after she noticed a lump in her left breast. Her maternal grandmother was diagnosed with ovarian cancer at the age of 54 years and died at the age of 60 years; her maternal aunt and mother were diagnosed with breast cancer at the ages of 36 and 40 years, respectively. The aunt died as a result of the disease at the age of 50 years. The patient is concerned that she may have inherited a genetic mutation that would predispose her to breast and/or ovarian cancer. Genetic testing of this patient and her mother are most likely to show a germline mutation in a component of which of the following pathways?
questions.explanation: BRCA gene mutation leads to defective homologous recombination. BRCA involves the breast, ovaries, and pancreas (while HER2 involves the breast stomach). BRCA1 is usually the culprit, although in men its usually BRCA2 mutations. HER2 is a oncogene (turn her on) while BRCA is a tumor suppressor.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old woman with a restrictive pulmonary disorder with no obstructive component is most likely to have which of the following sets of pulmonary volumes?
questions.explanation: Restrictive lung diseases have a decrease in everything because you restrict how much the lung can expand. The ratio of FEV1/FVC may be normal or high because everything decreased proportionately. Obstructive lung diseases have more RV, FRC, and TLC because of air trapping in lungs due to the obstruction, and the decreased FEV1/FVC is a hallmark, although a ratio of RV/TLC >35% seems to be a better criterion for diagnosis.

questions.stem: A 12-year-old girl is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three months ago, she sustained a complex fracture of the left tibia, which required cast immobilization. The cast is removed. Examination of the left calf shows that it is smaller than the right calf. Which of the following processes in this patient's myocytes is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation: Atrophy is a decrease in tissue mass due to a decrease in size. She has increased cytoskeleton degradation via the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway and autophagy plus decreased protein synthesis. Causes include disuse (her case), denervation, loss of blood supply, loss of hormonal stimulation, or poor nutrition.

questions.stem: A 56-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the onset of severe chest pain while mowing his lawn. His pulse is 110/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 105/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows cool, clammy, diaphoretic skin. Two hours after admission, pulmonary catheterization shows a pulmonary artery pressure of 40/25 mm Hg; the left atrial pressure is 25 mm Hg. Compared with a healthy person, which of the following sets of pulmonary pressure changes is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: Page 331 discusses shock. Page 313 discusses capillary fluid exchange. This patient has cardiogenic shock. Poor forward flow decreases CO increases the SVR, PCWP, and CVP. The extra blood increases capillary hydrostatic pressure, driving fluid into the interstitial space. Compared to the alveoli, the interstitial space now has more fluid so there is more hydrostatic pressure and less oncotic pressure. Now, fluid moves into the alveoli, causing pulmonary edema.

questions.stem: A 92-year-old woman who was recently admitted to a nursing home because of progressive dementia has large purpuric lesions over the dorsa of both forearms and hands. Her family states that she has had similar lesions on and off for years and that, to the best of their knowledge, these lesions occur in the absence of trauma. The woman appears well cared for and has no other indications of recent or remote injury. Her platelet count is normal. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for the purpura?
questions.explanation:
B. Not the same as actinic keratosis. This is also called solar purpura -- https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solar_purpura
Actinic purpura results from extravasation of blood into the dermis. This phenomenon is due to the skin atrophy and the fragility of the blood vessels in elderly individuals, which is exacerbated by chronic sun exposure. Actinic purpura lesions are located on sun-exposed areas, like the arms, face, and neck.
Skin atrophy in dermatoporosis is due to an alteration of collagen, similar to that which is seen in osteoporosis. This pronounced skin atrophy caused by the photo-aging makes the dermal vascular network very sensitive to the slightest trauma or shearing force.
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448130/

questions.stem: A newborn is born with a lethal chromosome defect. He is unable to suck sufficiently to maintain life. He has episodes of crying that occur every 2Â½ hours and are relieved by tube feeding. Which of the following best describes the most appropriate clinical approach?

options.text: Feed by whatever means necessary to maintain comfort
Give foods according to normal caloric requirement for age
Withhold feeding because of the severity of the diagnosis

questions.explanation:
The baby will die since this is a lethal defect.
Do no harm. Just provide palliative care until the death of the baby unless parents decide to pull the plug and end its life earlier.

questions.stem: A 48-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-hour history of dizziness and palpitations with a sustained, rapid, irregular heartbeat. An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. If amiodarone is administered, this patient is at greatest risk for which of the following adverse effects?
questions.explanation:
Amiodarone, a class III antiarrhythmic drug, has multiple effects on myocardial depolarization and repolarization that make it an extremely effective antiarrhythmic drug.
However, amiodarone is associated with a number of side effects, including thyroid dysfunction (both hypo- and hyperthyroidism), which is due to amiodarone's high iodine content and its direct toxic effect on the thyroid.

questions.stem: A 71-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of calf pain and discomfort when he walks more than two blocks; he is unable to walk farther than three blocks. The pain quickly subsides with rest. He also has hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. Physical examination shows weak dorsalis pedis pulses bilaterally and an ankle brachial index of 0.67. The physician knows of a drug that would improve this patient's symptoms and walking distance by altering platelet function and providing direct arterial vasodilation. This drug is most likely which of the following?
questions.explanation:
These medications increase cAMP in platelets and inhibit platelet aggregation. The phosphodiesterase inhibition also helps vasodilate. Cilostazol and Dipyridamole are the two medications in this class and they help with intermittent claudication (as seen in this patient) as well as coronary vasodilation (D used for stress test).
Can be used with Aspirin for TIA. These meds can cause facial flushing and abdominal pain.
Abciximab is a Gp2B/3A inhibitor that prevents platelet aggregation to help with unstable angina and PCI.
Clopidogrel is an ADP receptor inhibitor (prasugrel, ticagrelor, and ticlopidine too). These inhibit platelet aggregation by blocking ADP P2Y12 receptors to prevent the expression of Gp2B/3A.

questions.stem: Removal of the thymus at birth results in severely impaired immune responses. However, if the thymus is removed from adults, little if any deficit in immune responsiveness occurs because of which of the following reasons?

options.text: Antibody-producing lymphocytes are the most important cells for adult immunity
The bone marrow can take over the role of the thymus
Most antigens that elicit protective immunity in adults are thymus-independent
Thymic lymphocytes produced before thymectomy are long-lived
Thymic nerve cells sequestered in lymph nodes replace the need for thymic lymphocytes

questions.explanation: By age 75, the thymus is little more than fatty tissue. Fortunately, the thymus produces all of your T cells by the time you reach puberty. They are long-lived and that's why you can lose your thymus without impairment of your immune system. The naive T cells can live for up to 9 years and are stored in lymphoid organs, so a patient who gets a thymectomy (Such as in MG) will be fine.

questions.stem: The frequency of an autosomal recessive disease in a population is 1/1600. A deletion has been identified that accounts for 80% of the mutations at this locus. Twenty percent of the mutations result from point mutations. The frequency of deletion carriers in the population is closest to which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Use the Hardy-Weinberg equation discussed on page 57.
1- Take the square root of Q^2=1/1600, and that will give you the frequency of the recessive allele Q=1/40.
2- Calculate the frequency of the dominant allele with p+q=1, which is P= 39/40= 0.975 or approximately 1.
3- They are telling you to calculate the frequency of the disease carriers, which is with the equation 2pq, the heterozygotes.
4- They want only the disease carriers in which deletion is present.
To calculate this, use the q value (1/40) and multiply by 80% in this should give you 0.02.
5- Finally, calculate for 2PQ = 2 (0.975)(0.02) = 0.04 = 1/25.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old boy has a palpable mass in the ventral midline of the neck just inferior to the hyoid bone. This structure most likely developed from which of the following embryonic tissues?
questions.explanation:
Page 347 discusses thyroid development.

This is a thyroglossal duct cyst. The tyroglossal duct may persist and result in a thyroglossal duct cyst (occurring in midline near hyoid bone or at the base of the tongue), thus will classically move up with swallowing or tongue protrusion.

The foramen cecum (of the tongue) is the normal remnant of the thyroglossal duct

questions.stem: A 46-year-old man has dyspnea, orthopnea, and a midsystolic murmur that is best heard over the cardiac apex. An ECG shows a left atrial abnormality. Echocardiography shows an enlarged left atrium and a normally sized left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Page 301 discusses heart murmurs.

Remember that D-ARMS reminds you diastolic murmurs are aortic regurg and mitral stenosis, and this patient has a midsystolic murmur heard at the apex. The only answer choice worth picking now is mitral regurgitation, which is super common.

questions.stem: A 2-month-old girl is brought to the emergency department by her parents because of a 6-week history of constipation. She has also had poor feeding, sleepiness, and yellow skin during this period. Her parents are migrant workers, and she has not received routine medical care. Physical examination shows lethargy, hypotonia, jaundice, large fontanels, macroglossia, and an umbilical hernia. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step to establish the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Patient has congenital hypothyroidism (cretinism).
Findings: pot belly, pale, puffy-faced, umbilical hernia, macroglossia, hypotonia, poor brain development (MC cause of treatable mental retardation), large anterior fontanelles.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman has prolonged apnea following general anesthesia. Plasma cholinesterase activity is abnormal. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for the prolonged apnea in this patient?
questions.explanation: The duration of action of Succinylcholine is determined by its metabolism by plasma cholinesterase. So if there is abnormal plasma cholinesterase (=pseudocholinesterase), it will lead to delayed metabolism of succinylcholine as well as mivacurium, heroin, and cocaine.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a tooth abscess. He has not seen a physician or a dentist in over 10 years. He lives alone, is unemployed, and receives income from an inheritance. When asked what he does with his time, he says that he reads "books on physics." He has no friends, maintains minimal contact with relatives, and says that he is "really quite comfortable." Examination shows no symptoms of a thought disorder. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: This patient is voluntarily living alone and is doing just fine. There is nothing frantic or farfetch'd about the person. He is like an android. Schizoid.

questions.stem: A 59-year-old man develops fatigue and decreased appetite 3 months after receiving a mechanical aortic valve replacement. His pulse is 88/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 140/54 mm Hg. He appears tired. Physical examination shows mild scleral icterus. Jugular venous pressure is 8 cm HâO, and carotid upstrokes are normal. Lung fields are clear. Cardiac examination shows crisp prosthetic valve sounds and a grade 2/6, decrescendo diastolic murmur at the left sternal border. Abdominal examination shows no tenderness, normal liver size, and normal bowel sounds. Laboratory studies of serum show a total bilirubin concentration of 4 mg/dL and a direct bilirubin concentration of 1 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the jaundice in this patient?
questions.explanation: This patient has high indirect bilirubin because his indirect bilirubin production is too high, not because he is missing the enzyme to conjugate it. His complicated aortic valve is tearing the RBC. You would find schistocytes on peripheral blood smear, secondary to mechanical destruction of RBC.

questions.stem: A 4-week-old infant is brought to the emergency department because he has vomited after every feeding for the past 2 days. The most recent episode of vomiting was very forceful, with regurgitation through the nostrils. Physical examination shows mild abdominal distention with visible peristalsis. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Most common cause of gastric outlet obstruction in infants. Palpable olive-shaped mass in epigastric region, visible peristaltic waves, and nonbilious projectile vomiting at ~2-6 weeks old.

Ultrasound shows thickened and lengthened pylorus. Treatment is surgical incision (pyloromyotomy).

Duodenal atresia is associated with down syndrome and would have the double bubble. There would not be peristalsis.
TEF would present with choking spells and cyanosis due to food entering the trachea.
Zenker = Elder MIKE.
Meckel would cause RLQ pain and hematochezia.
Intussusception is painful with bloody stools.
Volvulus would not have peristalsis.

questions.stem: A 23-year-old woman, who was diagnosed with SjÃ¶gren syndrome 6 years ago, comes to the physician because she has had burning pain in her toes for the past month. She rates the pain as a 3 on a 10-point scale. She uses capsaicin cream as needed for the pain, which has produced partial relief. Medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Neurologic examination shows decreased perception of temperature over the feet bilaterally. Sensation to vibration, proprioception, reflexes, muscle strength, muscle tone, and bulk are normal. Which of the following neurotransmitters is most likely mediating this patient's pain?
questions.explanation:
An enkephalin is a pentapeptide involved in regulating nociception in the body.
The enkephalins are termed endogenous ligands, as they are internally derived and bind to the body's opioid receptors.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enkephalin

questions.info: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a 1-month history of pale skin. His parents are of European descent. He has no personal or family history of major medical illness. Physical examination shows pallor. Laboratory studies show:

infoImages.alt: Laboratory values showing hemoglobin, hematocrit, MCHC, and MCV

questions.stem: A photomicrograph of a peripheral blood smear is shown. Genetic testing is most likely to show which of the following findings in this patient?

options.text: Heterozygous mutation in the ankyrin gene
Heterozygous mutation in the Î±-globin gene
Heterozygous mutation in the Î²-globin gene
Homozygous mutation in the ankyrin gene
Homozygous mutation in the Î±-globin gene
Homozygous mutation in the Î²-globin gene

questions.explanation:
The histology is of spherocytes (small spherical cells w/o central pallor).
Hereditary spherocytosis is due to defect in proteins interacting with RBC membrane skeleton and plasma membrane (ankyrin, band 3, protein 4.2, spectrin).
Mostly autosomal dominant inheritance (so heterozygous mutation since you only need one mutant allele to get the disease).

questions.stem: A 23-year-old woman who is 6 months pregnant develops deep venous thrombosis. Intravenous administration of heparin is started. Seven days later, platelet count is 44,000/mmÂ³. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the decreased platelet count in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) is the development of IgG antibodies against heparin bound platelet factor 4(PF4).
Antibody-heparin-PF4 complex activates platelets; thrombosis and thrombocytopenia.
Highest risk with unfractionated heparin.

questions.stem: A 39-year-old man reports bright red spots on the toilet paper after defecating. Rectal examination shows large swollen rectal veins. Which of the following is the primary predisposing cause of these lesions?
questions.explanation:
Constipation is the main cause of hemorrhoids.
His swollen rectal veins are a sign of external hemorrhoids which are usually painful due to somatic pudendal innervation.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman has a thyroidectomy because of asymmetric enlargement of the thyroid gland, first noticed during a physical examination 6 weeks ago. She underwent an adrenalectomy for pheochromocytoma 3 years ago. Microscopically, the bilateral thyroid lesions are composed of spindle cells arranged in small clusters. Deposits of amyloid are present between neoplastic cells. Foci of C-cell hyperplasia are also present. The lesions are confirmed as malignant. Which of the following markers is most appropriate to monitor for the development of recurrence of the thyroid neoplasm?
questions.explanation:
This patient likely has MEN2 due to the involvement of medullary thyroid cancer and a pheochromocytoma.
The patient should have her parathyroid gland removed prophylactically and she should be examined for mucosal neuromas.

questions.stem: A 67-year-old woman comes to the physician for a health maintenance examination. Her brother and mother have a history of colon cancer. The physician recommends colonoscopy, but the patient says that she would prefer only for her stool to be tested for blood. The physician explains that testing the stool for occult blood is not appropriate in this case. The physician is most likely concerned about which of the following regarding this test?
questions.explanation:
Sensitivity tests are used for screening. Specificity tests are used for confirmation after positive screenings.

Sensitivity tests are used for seeing how many people truly have the disease.
Specificity tests are for those who do not have the disease.

A highly sensitive test, when negative, rules OUT disease. A highly specific test, when positive, rules IN disease.
So, a test with with low sensitivity cannot rule out a disease. A test with low specificity can't rule in disease.

The doctor and patient want to screen for colon cancer and rule it out. The doctor would want a test with high sensitivity to be able to do that. He knows that testing her stool for blood will not rule out the possibility of colon CA.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her husband because he found her in a semicomatose state with an empty bottle next to her. The bottle had contained a sodium salt of a drug with central nervous system effects. Alkalinization of her urine will cause the greatest absolute increase in elimination of the unmetabolized drug if it has which of the following pharmacokinetic profiles?

columns: Volume of Distribution at Steady State (L/kg)

questions.explanation:
In order for a drug to be cleared by the kidney, it must first be filtered in the glomeruli.
Drugs with a high VD have more of the drug in the tissue that are not available to filtered by the kidney. Drugs with high protein binding won't be filtered either. So you want a drug with low Vd and low binding if you want it cleared via the kidneys and urine.

A pKa 4-9 can be either weak acid or base. Weak acid pKa 4-7; strong acid pKa 1-3; Weak base pKa 7-9; strong base pKa above 9
Different pHs: stomach: 1-2 duodenum: 3-5 early jejunum: 6-7 late jejunum: 7-9 ileum: >9 urine: 4.5-8
Weak acids (pKa) gets absorbed in acidic (pH) environments and cleared in basic. Weak bases gets absorbed in basic environments and cleared in acidic.
THIS DOES NOT APPLY TO STRONG BASES OR ACIDS!!!!
The best explanation for this is a Biochem lecture from Pass Program -- https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mkBwZQPKEbg

questions.stem: A 22-year-old woman who recently emigrated from rural Mexico is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She has a 6-week history of headaches, nausea, vomiting, and decreased visual acuity. Funduscopic examination shows bilateral papilledema. An MRI of the brain shows enlargement of the right ventricle and findings consistent with cysticercosis. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of the hydrocephalus in this patient?

options.text: Obstruction of the right aperture of the fourth ventricle (foramen of Luschka)
Obstruction of the right interventricular foramen (foramen of Monro)

questions.explanation: This patient's presentation is indicative of increased intracranial pressure and the MRI confirms cysticercosis. Enlargement of the right ventricle only means there is an issue at the lateral ventricle, which comes before the foramina of monro, so that is where the obstruction must be.

questions.stem: During a clinical study, an investigator tests a new drug for the treatment of breast cancer. A population of 10,000 patients with breast cancer is recruited and randomized into a treatment group and control group. Analysis of the data shows a p-value of 0.1 and no significant difference in the treatment outcomes between the experimental group and the control group. When repeating this study, which of the following is most likely to decrease the likelihood of making a beta error?

options.text: Conduct the study for a shorter duration
Enroll participants with a different type of cancer

questions.explanation:
Increasing the sample size, effect size, or precision of tools will all increase power and decrease 1-beta, which is the type 2 error; a false negative error where you say there is no effect or difference even though there really is one (blindly let villain go).

The alpha level is the chance of making a type 1 error, which is really based off of a p-value being less than 0.05 and in our question the p-value is too high. So any alpha value could be just a result of chance alone. Furthermore, alpha, the chance of making a false-positive error, is rather independent of beta and type 2 errors.

questions.stem: A 13-year-old girl has an episode of severe cellular rejection necessitating maximal immunosuppression 6 months after a cadaveric renal transplantation. Two weeks later, she develops lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly. Examination of lymph node tissue obtained on biopsy shows a monomorphous population of B lymphocytes. Which of the following findings is most likely on further evaluation of these cells?
questions.explanation: EBV is known to lead to lymphoproliferative disease in transplant patients due to their immunosuppression.

questions.stem: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of pain in the left hip for 3 weeks. An x-ray of the hip shows a 4.5-cm, destructive, osteoblastic lesion with an associated fracture in the proximal femur and two separate similar smaller lesions in the bony pelvis. A needle core biopsy of the femur shows metastatic carcinoma. Which of the following is the most likely primary site of the cancer?
questions.explanation: Prostate cancer metastasizes via the prostatic venous plexus, which goes to the vertebral venous plexus and runs up the entire spinal column to connect to the brain through a valveless system, allowing bidirectional flow to regulate ICP. So prostate cancer can spread to the brain and lower back bones.

questions.info: A 23-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of excessive bleeding while brushing her teeth. Physical examination shows multiple ecchymoses. Laboratory studies show:

infoImages.alt: Laboratory values showing hemoglobin, leukocyte count, platelet count, and blasts

questions.stem: Intensive multidrug chemotherapy is planned. Before this treatment is initiated to decrease this patient's risk for kidney failure, it is most appropriate to administer a drug that inhibits or binds to which of the following sites?

options.text: Topoisomerase II (DNA gyrase) and topoisomerase IV

questions.explanation:
Allopurinol inhibits xanthine oxidase.
It is used for chronic gout as well as prevention of tumor-lysis associated urate nephropathy.
After tumor cells die, they release K+ and PO4. The K can lead to muscle weakness and cardiac issues.
The PO4 sequesters calcium leading to hypocalcemia which causes seizures and tetany.
The PO4 and calcium make calcium phosphate stones which damage the kidney along with the urate.

questions.stem: A 31-year-old woman receives a prescription for tetracycline and is instructed not to take the tetracycline with milk. If the tetracycline is taken with milk, its absorption is decreased due to which of the following effects?

options.text: Formation of complexes with mineral ions
Inhibition of intestinal cytochrome P450 enzymes

questions.explanation: Tetracyclines have a high affinity to form chelates with polyvalent metallic cations such as Fe+++, Fe++, Al+++, Mg++ and Ca++. Many of these tetracycline-metal complexes are either insoluble or otherwise poorly absorbable from the gastro-intestinal tract. Milk and other dairy products, antacids containing polyvalent cations, as well as various iron salts ingested simultaneously with tetracycline derivatives, might interfere with their absorption by 50 to 90% or even more. source: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/946598

questions.info: A new drug has the following effects on the activity of the primary arachidonic acid metabolites produced by neutrophils, platelets, mast cells, and endothelium:

infoImages.alt: Table showing drug effects on arachidonic acid metabolites by cell type

questions.stem: Which of the following is the most likely site of drug action?

image.alt: Arachidonic acid pathway diagram showing various enzymes and metabolites

questions.explanation: This patient is taking a medication that is only inhibiting neutrophil chemotaxis. LB4 is a potent chemotactic molecule for neutrophils.

questions.stem: A 55-year-old man with type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia develops severe myalgias with weakness. Serum creatine kinase activity is increased, and urine is positive for myoglobin. Which of the following drugs is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation: Statins can cause myopathy, specially when used concurrently with fibrates or niacin.

questions.stem: A 23-year-old man with a 3-year history of schizophrenia is brought to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has been taking an antipsychotic medication for auditory hallucinations, paranoia, and disorganized thinking for 2 years. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. During the interview, he does not make eye contact with the physician and occasionally turns his head when no one is talking as if he hears someone. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 120 mEq/L, urine sodium concentration of 8 mEq/L, and urine osmolality of 80 mOsmol/kg HâO. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's laboratory findings?

options.text: Resistance to the antidiuretic action of vasopressin

questions.explanation:
In psychogenic polydipsia, serum sodium concentration is low, and after water deprivation test, urine osmolality is increased. Urine osmolality does not increase with vasopressin injection.

In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, serum sodium concentration is high and there is no change/mild increase in urine osmolality after water deprivation.

Serum sodium concentration is based on whether or not water is being urinated, and if you are urinating too much water, serum sodium concentration will be high. If you are not urinating at all, serum sodium concentration will be low, such as in SIADH. If you drink too much water like this patient, serum sodium concentration will be low again.

questions.stem: A 2-year-old child undergoes resection of the right kidney because of chronic infections secondary to reflux. The left kidney is grossly normal. Which of the following structural adaptations will eventually occur in the left kidney?
questions.explanation:
Other kidney Hypertrophies due to increased stress.
There will not be any hyperplasia because its not about a cancer.

questions.stem: A 3-month-old boy is brought to the physician because of facial abnormalities and weakness since birth. Physical examination shows coarse facial features and hypotonia. Urinary excretion of mucopolysaccharides is within the reference range. The concentrations of lysosomal enzymes are increased in serum and decreased in cultured skin fibroblasts. Which of the following molecular markers is most likely decreased in this patient's lysosomal enzymes?
questions.explanation:
I-cell disease (inclusion cell disease/mucolipidosis type II)âinherited lysosomal storage disorder; defect in N-acetylglucosaminy1-1-phosphotransferase â failure of the Golgi to phosphorylate mannose residues (forming mannose-6-phosphate) on glycoproteins â proteins are secreted extracellularly rather than delivered to lysosomes.
Results in coarse facial features, gingival hyperplasia, clouded corneas, restricted joint movements, claw hand deformities, kyphoscoliosis, and high plasma levels of lysosomal enzymes. Often fatal in childhood.

questions.info: An 83-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being found at home bedridden and confused. He takes no medications. Temperature is 35.6Â°C (96Â°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 85/50 mm Hg. Blood pressure is unchanged after intravenous infusion of 1 liter of isotonic saline. A pulmonary artery catheter is inserted and the following findings are obtained:

infoImages.alt: Table showing cardiac output (high), pulmonary capillary wedge pressure (low), and systemic vascular resistance (low)

questions.stem: Which of the following is the most likely cause of the hypotension?
questions.explanation:
Septic shock is a type of distributive shock which is marked by massive vasodilation (d/t inflammatory response) causing decreased SVR, decreased preload / PCWP, and increased CO.

Distributive shock is a collective term for shock that results in pathologic vasodilation, leading to decreased SVR. The most common etiology is septic shock but it can also be caused by neurogenic shock (CO & HR would also be low) or anaphylactic shock.
