Circulating cytokines and bacterial toxins cause pathologic vasodilation and lead to decreased SVR (afterload), as well as decreased CVP and PCWP (preload). Consequently, there is an increase in heart rate and cardiac output. Patients with septic shock will often have warm, flushed skin as a result of this pathophysiology.

questions.stem: In patients with breast cancer, metabolically stable agonists of gonadotropin-releasing hormone are effective because they inhibit release of which of the following?
questions.explanation: GnRH agonists like Leuprolide are effective for patients with breast CA because if given in a continuous fashion, they downregulate the GnRH receptor in the pituitary and ultimately decrease FSH and LH.

questions.stem: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-week history of muscle cramps, accompanied by painful spasms in his arms and legs. He tells the physician that, for the past 4 months, he has had trouble opening jars and using silverware. Examination shows muscle weakness and exaggerated deep tendon reflexes. An appropriate treatment of the muscle cramps and spasms in this patient includes systemic administration of a drug with which of the following mechanisms of action?

options.text: Agonist at Î³-aminobutyric acid B (GABAB) receptors
Blockade of acetylcholine release from nerve terminals

questions.explanation: This patient likely has some form of upper motor neuron lesion or disease - UMN lesions are characterized by weakness, increased deep tendon reflexes, and spastic paresis. Baclofen is a GABA-B agonist specific to the spinal cord, used to treat muscle spasticity, dystonia, and MS. GABA-B is a G-protein coupled receptor coupled to Gi, so agonism of this receptor causes hyperpolarization of the neurons and decreased release of excitatory glutamate.

questions.stem: A 62-year-old woman comes to the physician because of progressive bilateral lower abdominal pain and distention during the past month. Pelvic examination shows an adnexal mass on the right. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a 6 x 6-cm mass in the right ovary with an internal echo pattern highly suggestive of ovarian cancer. Microscopic examination of peritoneal fluid obtained by paracentesis shows malignant cells. Paclitaxel therapy is initiated. This treatment will target which of the following in this patient's tumor?
questions.explanation:
Remember "taxes stabilize society" and understand that this stabilizes M phase.
Beta-Tubulin is a subunit of tubulin. Tubulin is one of several members of a small family of globular proteins.
It is the major constituent of microtubules.
There are two of most common members of the tubulin family: alpha-tubulin and beta-tubulin,
and together their dimers form microtubules.

questions.stem: A 19-year-old woman has severe refractory pustular acne that has been unresponsive to several topical and systemic therapies. Treatment with daily oral isotretinoin is begun. Which of the following pharmacologic effects of this drug is dependent on its binding to the RXR receptor?

options.text: Trafficking of neutrophils through endothelial tight junctions

questions.explanation:
Remember IsoTERATinoin.
Isotretinoin is used to treat severe cystic acne. It is a teratogen. Can cause multiple severe birth defects. Contraception is mandatory. RXR is a retinoid X receptor.

questions.stem: A 54-year-old woman with terminal metastatic pancreatic cancer comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She asks the physician to prescribe her a sufficient quantity of medication to allow her to commit suicide if the pain becomes unbearable. The physician refuses to do so, but he informs the patient that he will do everything he can to manage her pain. The physician's decision in this situation is most consistent with which of the following ethical principles?
questions.explanation:
This question is too vague. It is easily arguable that this is beneficence in which the doctor is acting out what is best for the patient, but also against the autonomy of the patient, but remember that the patient interest supersedes.

This is nonmaleficence. The doctor must do no harm and this has to be balanced with beneficence, so the benefits must outweigh the risk and the patient must make an informed decision.

questions.stem: A 22-year-old woman comes to the emergency department because of a 2-hour history of fever, chills, and muscle aches. Six hours ago, she received an injection of penicillin G benzathine for syphilis. Her temperature is 38.9Â°C (102Â°F). Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Which of the following best explains this patient's symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Administration of Penicillin for Syphilis may lead to the Jarisch-Herxheimer reaction hours after treatment.
Occurs due to lysis of spirochetes (so it can occur with Borrelia and Leptospirosis as well).
The reaction is characterized by fever and chills.

The classical explanation of the Herxheimer reaction is that treatment results in the sudden death and destruction of large numbers of treponemes, with the liberation of protein products and toxins.

questions.stem: An 18-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fever, a severe sore throat, and fatigue for 1 week. Her temperature is 38.1Â°C (100.6Â°F). Physical examination shows pharyngeal erythema, generalized tender lymphadenopathy, and splenomegaly. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 4400/mmÂ³ with 20% atypical lymphocytes. Which of the following cell types most likely accounts for the atypical lymphocytes in this patient's peripheral blood?
questions.explanation:
This young woman probably has EBV, which infects B cells through CD21.
Atypical lymphocytes on peripheral blood smear G ânot infected B cells but reactive cytotoxic T cells.
â Monospot testâheterophile antibodies detected by agglutination of sheep or horse RBCs.
Use of amoxicillin in mononucleosis can cause characteristic maculopapular rash.

questions.stem: Two days after admission to the hospital because of drug-induced thrombocytopenia, a 37-year-old woman develops a severe headache and becomes comatose. On admission, examination showed a few petechiae over the lower extremities, and her platelet count was 5000/mmÂ³. A CT scan of the head shows an intracranial hemorrhage. A platelet transfusion is recommended, but the patient is a Jehovah's Witness and had stated on admission that she did not want to receive transfusion of any blood products. Her husband is not a Jehovah's Witness and wants her to have the transfusion. Which of the following is the most appropriate management regarding transfusion?

options.text: Do not proceed with the transfusion
Obtain consent from the hospital ethics committee
Obtain consent from the patient's husband
Obtain consent from the patient's minister
Proceed with the transfusion without consent

questions.explanation: The only time you transfuse a Jehovah's Witness patient is when the patient is a minor (<18 years old).

questions.stem: An 18-year-old woman comes to the physician to request screening for colon cancer. Her father and grandfather died of colon cancer at the ages of 36 and 45 years, respectively. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Colonoscopy shows approximately 200 lesions throughout the colon. A colectomy is done, and a section of the colon removed is shown in the photograph. Which of the following is the chance that this patient's offspring will eventually develop adenocarcinoma of the colon?

image.alt: Pathology image showing multiple colonic lesions

questions.explanation:
Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant mutation (so is Lynch).
Thousands of polyps arise starting after puberty; pancreatic; always involves rectum.
Prophylactic colectomy or else 100% progress to CRC.

Autosomal dominant diseases have, on average, 50% chance of being passed to offspring.

questions.stem: A 41-year-old woman with systemic lupus erythematosus is scheduled to undergo surgical placement of a peritoneal dialysis catheter. The surgeon asks the resident physician to get the consent form signed the evening before the procedure. The resident has never seen this procedure performed and has read little about it. He will not be assisting with the procedure. Which of the following actions by the resident physician is most appropriate?

options.text: Ask a nurse to get a signature on the form
Ask the attending physician to obtain informed consent
Ask the patient to sign the form and tell her that the surgeon will answer questions the next morning
Obtain an informed consent by explaining what he believes is the major risk
Try to answer any of the patient's questions concerning the procedure

questions.explanation: Informed consent should be obtained by a provider who has sufficient knowledge to give accurate description of the intervention, the risks and benefits of treatment, and able to answer all of the px question. This is the explanation for a very similar qx in Uworld.

questions.stem: A 23-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of weakness and muscle pain after vigorous exercise. His mother, sister, and grandmother have a similar condition; however, his father and his mother's brother and children are unaffected. A muscle biopsy specimen shows ragged red fibers. This condition most likely results from a mutation in a gene located in which of the following labeled structures in the photomicrograph?

image.alt: Electron micrograph of muscle cell with labeled structures A through E

questions.explanation:
This video helps understand the electron microscopy of organelles--
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k0YqEpA-62A

This patient has mitochondrial myopathy.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old woman develops proteinuria and hematuria. She has taken 3 g of ibuprofen for headaches almost daily for the past 2 years. Which of the following findings is most likely in tissue obtained on renal biopsy?
questions.explanation:
This patient who has been taking ibuprofen is now presenting with acute interstitial nephritis due to the NSAID acting as a hapten and inducing an IgE mediated type 4 hypersensitivity. The 5 P's remind you of the medications that can cause this, but it can also be secondary to lupus or autoimmune disease.

ATN is the most common cause of renal injury in hospitalized patients, presenting first with oliguria, uremia, and metabolic acid, followed by a polyurin re-epithelialization recovery phase with a risk of hypokalemia.

DCN is usually related to vasospasm and DIC related to obstetric catastrophes and septic shock.

RPN has gross hematuria triggered by infection in sickle cell or diabetic patients.

questions.stem: A 4-year-old boy has had fever, abdominal cramping, and repeated bloody mucoid stools with tenesmus over the past 3 days. Several other children at his day-care center have a similar illness. Direct microscopic examination of a methylene blue-stained fecal smear shows numerous neutrophils. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.explanation:
Methylene-blue stained fecal smear revealed numerous neutrophils (but not any organisms).
Shigella is colorless when stained with methylene blue; E coli stains blue with methylene blue because it ferments lactose.

Shigella causes an inflammatory diarrhea; it produces a toxin and can invade tissue directly. In addition, it is resistant to acid, so it has a characteristically low infective dose (~10 organisms), which facilitates its fecal-oral (person-to-person) spread especially in settings where hygiene may be compromised, such as in daycare or institutional housing. It can be differentiated from E. Coli (EHEC) because E Coli doesn't have as much person-to-person spread and only causes GI damage by the shiga-like toxin, not a direct invasion. Therefore, EHEC wouldn't facilitate as strong of a neutrophilic response.

Tenesmus refers to cramping rectal pain. Tenesmus gives you the feeling that you need to have a bowel movement, even if you already have had one. When you have tenesmus, you might strain harder to produce only a small amount of stool during bowel movements. Tenesmus is pretty specific to Shigella, too.

questions.stem: A 35-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 2-month history of inflamed thickened skin covered with silvery scales on the scalp, trunk, elbows, and knees. This condition has been poorly responsive to coal tar preparations, calcipotriene, and triamcinolone cream. Which of the following drugs is the most appropriate next step in treatment?
questions.explanation:
Methotrexate would be a drug of choice for psoriasis refractory to topical creams and light therapy; inhibits dihydrofolate reductase in order to decrease skin cell proliferation and reduce inflammatory response.
Calcipotriene is a vitamin D analog that inhibits keratinocyte differentiation.
Ustekinumab is a monoclonal antibody that stops CD4 differentiation to treat psoriasis.
Etanercept can also help treat severe, plaque-type psoriasis.

questions.stem: A 62-year-old man with alcohol-induced liver disease develops massive ascites. Infection is ruled out. The most appropriate diuretic treatment, in addition to loop diuretics, includes which of the following drugs?
questions.explanation:
Clinical use of K-sparing diuretics:

Hyperaldosteronism
K+ depletion
HF
hepatic ascites (spironolactone)
nephrogenic DI (amiloride)
antiandrogen

Patients with hepatic ascites have hyperaldosteronism; because the intravascular volume is escaped to third space(ascites). So adding spironolactone is a good choice.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife because of personality changes for 2 years and cognitive decline for 3 months. His wife says, 'He used to be such a kind and shy man, but now he screams at strangers for no apparent reason.' Neurologic examination shows a palmomental reflex and hyperreflexia throughout the upper and lower extremities. His mood appears normal except for occasional inappropriate cursing at the physician. His Mini-Mental State Examination score is 21/30. A CT scan of the head shows disproportionate atrophy of the frontal lobes bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Page 564 discusses Pick disease. Frontotemporal dementia (formerly known as Pick disease): Early changes in personality and behavior (behavioral variant), or aphasia (primary progressive aphasia). May have associated movement disorders (eg, parkinsonism).

questions.stem: A 72-year-old woman with dysphagia is undergoing surgical evaluation of a mass in the posterior mediastinum. During this procedure, the thoracic duct is inadvertently damaged near the mass. This injury is most likely to impair the normal lymphatic return of which of the following structures?
questions.explanation: Page 96 discusses lymphatic drainage and the thoracic duct. The left upper extremity and breast are drained by the axillary lymph node. The kidney is drained by the thoracic duct.

questions.stem: A 26-year-old man undergoes an abdominal exploratory operation after sustaining a stab wound in the left upper quadrant. He is found to have a laceration of the fundus of the stomach. During mobilization and repair of the stomach, he develops heavy bleeding due to damage to one of the short gastric arteries. The short gastric arteries branch from which of the following arteries?
questions.explanation:
Branches of the celiac trunk are the left gastric, common hepatic, and splenic.
The splenic gives the short gastric for the fundus and the left gastroepiploic for the left greater curvature.

questions.stem: A 56-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-month history of worsening fatigue and moderate lower extremity edema. He has a 15-year history of poorly controlled hypertension. His blood pressure is 195/110 mm Hg. Serum urea nitrogen (BUN) concentration is 70 mg/dL, and serum creatinine concentration is 7.0 mg/dL. A 24-hour urine sample contains 300 mg of protein. Which of the following is the most likely pathologic finding in the kidneys?

options.text: Inflammatory cell infiltrate in the interstitium
Large electron-dense deposits in the glomeruli

questions.explanation:
Hyperplastic arteriolosclerosis involves thickening of vessel wall by hyperplasia of smooth muscle ('onion-skin appearance').

Consequence of malignant hypertension (>180/120 w/ acute end-organ damage).
Results in reduced vessel caliber with end-organ ischemia.
May lead to fibrinoid necrosis of the vessel wall with hemorrhage;
classically causes acute renal failure (ARF) with a characteristic 'flea-bitten' appearance.

Robbin's: Fibromuscular dysplasia is a focal irregular thickening of the walls of medium-sized and large muscular arteries due to a combination of medial and intimal hyperplasia and fibrosis. It can manifest at any age but occurs most frequently in young women. The local thickening results in luminal stenosis or can be associated with abnormal vessel spasm that reduces vascular flow; in the renal arteries, it can lead to renovascular hypertension. Between the focal segments of thickened wall, the artery often also exhibits medial attenuation; vascular outpouchings can develop in these portions of the vessel and sometimes rupture.

questions.stem: An otherwise healthy 4-month-old girl is brought to the physician because of the lesion shown. The lesion has been present for 2 months but has grown rapidly over the past 3 weeks. Which of the following is expected over the next 5 years?

image.alt: Strawberry hemangioma lesion on infant's face

options.text: Continued enlargement as the child grows

questions.explanation: The strawberry hemangiomas tend to grow and then randomly involute.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of a discharge from both breasts. She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. She takes hydrochlorothiazide. Physical examination shows a thin, milky discharge from both breasts. Which of the following mechanisms is most likely responsible for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
The internet does not know how this is the answer. But its not breast cancer, because the discharge is bilateral.
Diabetes and hypertension do not fit the issue either. Systemic mastocytosis is related mast cell proliferation and increased histamine secretion leading to gastric hypersecretion with ulceration and some skin manifestations like flushing.

questions.stem: A 38-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of sore throat. During the examination, the patient is asked to protrude the tongue and say "ah," which causes elevation of the area at the tip of the arrow in the photograph shown. Function of which of the following nerves most likely is being tested by this maneuver?

image.alt: Photograph showing uvula elevation during examination

questions.explanation:
Cranial nerve 10 checks the uvula. The uvula deviates away from the side of the lesion because the weak side collapses, so the uvula points away.

CN5 lesions causes the jaw to deviate toward the lesion, while CN12 lesions cause the tongue to deviate toward the lesion. CN11 leads to a weakened SCM muscle, making it hard to turn ur head the opposite way but the shoulder drops on the ipsilateral side.

questions.stem: A 34-year-old man who is HIV positive is brought to the emergency department because of severe abdominal pain for 12 hours. He has been receiving antiretroviral therapy for the past 2 weeks. Prior to starting this medication, his CD4+ T-lymphocyte count was 35/mmÂ³ (N >500). In addition, he was diagnosed 14 days ago with disseminated Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare infection by a positive blood culture and enlarged intra-abdominal lymph nodes on CT scan. His temperature is 39Â°C (102.2Â°F), pulse is 104/min, and blood pressure is 110/84 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Abdominal examination shows tenderness. A CT scan of the abdomen shows further enlargement of the lymph nodes since the previous CT. Improved function of which of the following cells is required for the development of these findings?
questions.explanation:
CD4+ cells activate B-cells which form follicles and cause enlargement of lymph nodes.
Therefore, in an AIDS patient, to enlarge the lymph nodes, the CD4+ dysfunction must be resolved.

questions.stem: A 6-week-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother because of a 6-day history of vomiting a small amount of milk 2 to 3 times daily. She appears well. She is at the 50th percentile for length and weight. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.explanation:
More at this video and in the description of the video.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DFcySw14rlo
The baby is fine with no major failure to thrive. The 50th percentile part was overexaggerated.
Typical NBME bullshit and other choices dont fit.

Spasm would have dysphagia and angina-like chest pain with corkscrew barium of esophagus.
Pyloric stenosis would have nonbilious projectile vomiting. TEF would have cyanosis due to laryngospasm.
Malrotation and volvulus (midgut in infants) would have physical exam findings of abdominal distention.

questions.stem: A 66-year-old man has had fatigue, shortness of breath, and temperatures to 40Â°C (104Â°F) for a week. An x-ray of the chest shows a cavitary lesion with a fluid level in the right lower lobe of the lungs. Culture of sputum grows Klebsiella pneumoniae. Symptoms resolve with antibiotic treatment. Which of the following is most likely to be found in the right lower lobe 6 months later?
questions.explanation:
A radiographically visible air-fluid level suggests a pretty large lesion (hence, "cavitary").
That's not going to become normal tissue again.
Six months following resolution of symptoms you can expect healing in the form of a scar;
that is, fibrosis but only in a single spot.

questions.stem: A 75-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a burning, itching sensation on the right side of her chest for 7 days and a rash in this same area for the past 3 days. Her temperature is 37.3Â°C (99.1Â°F). Examination shows clustered skin lesions overlying two ribs near the right axillary line in the mid-thorax and on the back near the right scapula. Some of the lesions are fluid-filled blisters and others have crusty scabs. Light microscopy is most likely to show which of the following findings?

options.text: Branching fungal hyphae without yeast forms
Diffuse separation of dermis and epidermis
Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae
Immunofluorescent staining for C3 along the epidermal basement membrane
Multinucleated giant cells and neutrophil infiltrates
Nonbranching fungal hyphae with abundant yeast forms

questions.explanation:
This is an example of Shingles.
Herpes simplex and herpes zoster viruses cause abnormal cell division in epidermal cells, and this creates multinucleated giant cells.

A Tzank smear showing multinucleated giant cells is characteristic of Varicella Zoster Virus infections. (HSV will have similar findings).
Other identifying terms for herpes: Single dermatome (does not cross the midline), painful (burning and itching), and lesions in multiple stages.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old woman with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the emergency department because of a 16-hour history of substernal chest pain that radiates to the left arm. Her pulse is 110/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs. A diagnosis of acute myocardial infarction is made. Two days later, the patient develops acute respiratory distress. Physical examination shows jugular venous distention to the angle of the jaw. Crackles are heard over the lower half of the lung fields. A grade 4/6, apical systolic murmur is now heard. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of this patient's worsening condition?
questions.explanation:
The two most important MI complications that occur within a 2-5 day span are papillary muscle rupture and interventricular septum rupture.

Papillary muscle rupture leads to severe mitral regurgitation, heard as a systolic murmur at the apex.

questions.stem: A 28-year-old man who is a migrant worker comes to the clinic because of fatigue and back pain for 6 weeks. He has had a 6-kg (13-lb) weight loss during this period. His temperature is 38.3Â°C (100.9Â°F). When placed in the supine position, the patient holds his right lower extremity in rigid extension. A PPD skin test result shows 16 mm of induration. X-rays of the chest and spine confirm the diagnosis of tuberculosis with infection of the lumbar vertebrae. Spread of this infection from the lumbar vertebrae is most likely causing this patient to guard which of the following muscles while he is in the supine position?

explanationImage.alt: Cross-sectional anatomy showing psoas muscle and lumbar vertebrae

questions.explanation: This patient has a Psoas major abscess.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 6-week history of cough productive of blood-tinged sputum. He also has had a 3-kg (6.6-lb) weight gain during the past 8 weeks. He has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years. His blood pressure is 165/101 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. A CT scan of the chest shows a suprahilar pulmonary lesion. Laboratory studies show a serum sodium concentration of 122 mEq/L. The physician suspects that this laboratory abnormality is related to the pulmonary lesion. Which of the following sets of additional laboratory findings is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation:
This patient has small cell carcinoma. This type of cancer is associated with paraneoplastic syndromes such as:
Cushing Syndrome, SIADH, or antibodies against Ca2+ channels (Lambert-Eaton) or neurons.
Amplification of myc oncogenes is also common.

SIADH (Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion) is characterized by:

Excessive free water retention
Euvolemic hyponatremia with continued urinary Na+ excretion
Urine osmolality > serum osmolality
Body responds to water retention with aldosterone and ANP and BNP. That is what causes the increased
urinary Na+ secretion which leads to normalization of extracellular fluid volume and the euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.stem: A 9-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of poor growth during the past year. She is below the 3rd percentile for height and at the 10th percentile for weight. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Visual field testing shows bitemporal hemianopia. Laboratory studies show growth hormone deficiency. An MRI of the brain shows a calcified cystic mass in the suprasellar region. This tumor is most likely derived from which of the following?

options.text: Diverticulum of the roof of the embryonic oral cavity
Ependymal layer of the median eminence
Neural crest cells of the rhombencephalon

questions.explanation:
Patient has a craniopharyngioma. Most common childhood supratentorial tumor. Derived from remnants of Rathke pouch (oral ectoderm).
Calcification is common. Cholesterol crystals found in "motor oil"-like fluid within tumor.

A cystic suprasellar mass with calcifications and enhancement of the wall or solid portions in a child or adolescent is almost always a craniopharyngioma.

May be confused with pituitary adenoma (both cause bitemporal hemianopia).

questions.stem: The sequence surrounding the first two exons of the human Î²-globin gene is shown, with the exons given in bold capital letters. The translation start codon is underlined. A mutation from GâA at position 355 (bold italics) is most likely to lead to Î²-thalassemia by which of the following mechanisms?

image.alt: DNA sequence of human Î²-globin gene showing exons and mutation site

options.text: Creation of a missense mutation that leads to the synthesis of a defective Î²-globin
Disruption of normal splicing by creation of a new 3' splice site
Disruption of polyadenylation of the mRNA
Inhibition of the replication of this gene

questions.explanation: The splicing usually happens at GT-AG, and you can see that the current splicing end areas are from 241 to 361, where the intron starts with a GT and ends with an AG on those respective lines. Now, with the mutation described, there will be an earlier AG, so the rest from there on will be added on to the exon, possibly making the exon dysfunctional, leading to disease.

questions.stem: A 70-year-old man dies of coronary artery disease. He had a cerebral infarction 8 years ago. A photograph of a specimen of the brain stem is shown. Which of the following neurologic deficits was most likely present in this patient after his cerebral infarction?

image.alt: Brain specimen showing left and right hemispheres

explanationImage.alt: Cross-section of brain stem with anatomical labels

options.text: Loss of joint position sense in the left extremities
Loss of joint position sense in the right extremities

questions.explanation:
The area that lost the dark on the left side is the area of the infarction. His left crus cerebri is now pale; it contains many descending fibers.

This contains the corticospinal tract. Since the corticospinal tract decussates at the medulla, below the midbrain section we're looking at, you would see Contralateral (Right) Spastic Hemiparesis

questions.stem: A 33-year-old woman comes to the emergency department 1 hour after she slipped on an icy sidewalk and fell onto her outstretched right hand. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness to palpation centrally of the palmar side of the right wrist. Palpation of the right anatomical snuffbox and the remaining portion of the wrist elicits no pain. The most likely cause of the findings in this patient is dislocation of which of the following bones?
questions.explanation:
Capitate and lunate are in the center of the palm. Capitate is not an option, so lunate is the answer.

Dislocation of lunate may cause acute carpal tunnel syndrome.
Hook of the Hamate is related to guyan canal syndrome in bikers, due to ulnar trapping.
And the scaphoid can be injured in a fall like this patient's, but the anatomical snuff box would elicit pain.

questions.info: A 36-year-old man comes to the physician because he has not urinated for the past 24 hours. He has a 3-day history of decreased urine output. He has had intermittent renal calculi during the past 5 years. His temperature is 36.9Â°C (98.4Â°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 150/96 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. Serum studies show:

infoImages.alt: Lab values showing electrolyte levels including elevated potassium

questions.stem: Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows bilateral hydronephrosis. Bilateral nephrostomy tubes are placed. Which of the following best predicts the most likely changes in urine output and urine potassium excretion that will occur during the next 24 hours?
questions.explanation:
The tubes are catheters put in for urine to flow into a bag. So urine output is going to increase.
The patient is also hyperkalemic. Aldosterone responds to hyperkalemia by increasing K+ excretion.

Hyperkalemia will stimulate aldosterone secretion even if renin is suppressed due to his hypertension.
Although Na+ will be reabsorbed, this will be transient (should resolve once the potassium levels
normalized) and since his urine output will most likely return to normal, his blood pressure should also normalize.

Postobstructive diuresis is a polyuric state in which copious amounts of salt and water are eliminated
after the relief of a urinary tract obstruction.

questions.stem: A 56-year-old man is admitted to the hospital after an automobile collision that resulted in crush injuries to both legs. Thirty-six hours later he develops oliguria, hyperkalemia, and an increased serum urea nitrogen (BUN) concentration. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?
questions.explanation:
Rhabdomyolysis can present looking like a kidney injury (it can lead to acute tubular necrosis as well).
The electrolyte findings are just like renal failure (Inc. K+, inc. PO4-, dec. Ca)

To differentiate between rhabdomyolysis and kidney injury, you check the urine to see if there are any RBCs.
In rhabdomyolysis there are no free RBCs in the urine.
"Crush injury" is practically a buzz word for rhabdomyolysis.

questions.stem: A 37-year-old nurse is accidentally stuck with a needle used to obtain blood from a patient who is HIV positive. Because of the severity of the exposure, she receives three antiretroviral agents. Four weeks later, she develops anemia and neutropenia. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of these antiretroviral agents that is most likely responsible for the anemia and neutropenia?

options.text: Prevents binding to the CD4 molecule
Prevents release of virus from the infected cell

questions.explanation:
NRTI's are associated with possible side effects of anemia, granulocytopenia, and myelosuppression.
In other words this question is easy because its just asking what would cause anemia, and if you stop transcription you stop making hemoglobin.

From the NRTI here are special notes-
1] Tenofovir is the only nucleotide.
2] Abacavir has hypersensitivity risk in HLAB5701 patients.
3] ZDV causes anemia, didanosine causes pancreatitis, and the rest can all cause lactic acidosis.
4] G-CSF can reverse the bone marrow suppression.

From NNRTI just remember Efavirenzzz can cause vivid dreams, while all 3 can cause rash and hepatotoxicity.

questions.stem: A 1-month-old male newborn is brought to the emergency department by his mother because of a 5-day history of vomiting after feedings. His mother says the vomiting is forceful, and appears to contain only formula. She says he seems eager to feed after each episode. He appears irritable. He is at the 25th percentile for length and weight. His temperature is 37Â°C (98.7Â°F), pulse is 140/min, respirations are 24/min, and blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows decreased skin turgor. Which of the following sets of serum findings (in mEq/L) is most likely in this newborn at this time?
questions.explanation:
Since the vomit has no bile, this is the most common cause of GI obstruction in infants 2-6 weeks of age so that is most likely the case here.
Vomiting loses HCl so you get low Cl and the renal compensation of H loss is preserving more H at the expense of K, leading to low K.

questions.stem: A 24-year-old African American man comes to the physician because of a 3-month history of red bumps on his face and chin. He says that the bumps are itchy and painful. Physical examination shows hyperpigmented papules over the cheeks, jawline, and neck. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Foreign body inflammatory facial skin disorder characterized by firm, hyper-pigmented papules and pustules that are painful and pruritic. Located on cheeks, jawline, and neck.

Commonly occurs as a result of shaving ("razor bumps"), primarily affects African-American males.

questions.stem: A mother who has toxoplasmosis gives birth to an asymptomatic female newborn. Which of the following tests on the newborn will indicate that the newborn has congenital Toxoplasma gondii infection?
questions.explanation:
The baby does not get any maternal IgM, IgA or IgE as they do not cross the placenta, so if IgM is found it may suggest the baby has encountered an infection in utero.

IgG is passed down to the baby as a means of passive immunity until the baby can form their own antibodies of different types. So if you see anything other than IgG (e.g. IgM) you know it must be due to an infection.

questions.info: Serum cholesterol concentrations are measured as part of a community study. The mean and standard deviation are given for women by age group:

infoImages.alt: Table showing cholesterol levels by age group with mean and standard deviation

questions.stem: Assuming serum cholesterol concentrations follow a normal (gaussian) distribution, which of the following is the probability that a woman between the ages of 50 and 54 years has a serum cholesterol concentration greater than 296 mg/dL?
questions.explanation:
The question wants to know how many people fall at 1SD above 296.
We know 68% fall within 1 SD, so 32% left will be above or below 1 SD.
Thus, 16% must be above and 16% below.

questions.stem: A 53-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of intermittent abdominal pain. She has a history of multiple episodes of traveler's diarrhea and urinary tract infections. She is an avid traveler to the Middle East, South America, and Asia. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 10,300/mmÂ³ (55% segmented neutrophils, 10% eosinophils, and 35% lymphocytes). A photomicrograph of a stool sample is shown. Which of the following infectious agents is the most likely cause of the findings in this patient?

image.alt: Microscopic image of parasitic organism in stool sample

questions.explanation:
This photomicrograph is S mansoni, with its lateral spine.
S haemotobium has a terminal spine while S japonicum has a nubby lateral spine that is short.

questions.stem: A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of progressive shortness of breath during the past month. Two weeks ago, she underwent coronary artery bypass grafting at the left base of the chest. Her respirations are 26/min. There is dullness to percussion at the left base of the chest. A chest x-ray shows substantial fluid in the left pleural cavity. Thoracentesis yields 1200 mL of pale, milky fluid that is identified as chyle. Which of the following procedures during the operation most likely produced the iatrogenic chylothorax?

explanationImage.alt: Left thoracic anatomy diagram showing lymphatic structures

options.text: Dissection of the internal thoracic artery
Placement of the central line via the left internal jugular vein
Placement of the epicardial pacemaker lead
Placement of the pulmonary artery catheter via the right subclavian vein

questions.explanation:
This is the only choice that comes close to nicking the thoracic duct, specifically at its inlet, the left subclavian.

This is why its better to use the right subclavian vein.

questions.stem: A 60-year-old man has two-pillow orthopnea, severe dyspnea, and edema of the lower extremities. The onset of these symptoms was preceded by an episode of prolonged substernal chest pain 5 days ago. Which of the following additional findings on examination of the neck is most consistent with these findings?

options.text: Carotid bruit best heard at the carotid bifurcation
Jugular venous pressure of 12 mm Hg

questions.explanation:
The patient has evidence of HF and the normal JVP is 6-8mmHg. This patient would have JVD.

Bifid carotid pulses are seen in Aortic stenosis or regurgitation.

Carotid Bruit is heard with atherosclerosis of common carotid artery.

Slow rising decreased volume carotid pulse is characteristic of aortic stenosis.

Cannon "a" waves are seen in complete AV block, as right ventricle and atrium contract independently and the right atrium ends up contracting against a closed tricuspid valve.

questions.stem: A 30-year-old man who completed a successful course of treatment for Hodgkin disease 2 months ago calls his physician on an increasingly frequent basis. He takes his temperature several times daily and contacts the office whenever it is above 37.2Â°C (99Â°F). He also has episodes of tingling of his fingers that last several seconds. Although evaluation has shown no evidence of recurrence, he is increasingly fearful that Hodgkin disease may not be detected rapidly enough for successful treatment. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Definition of adjustment disorder:

Emotional symptoms (eg, anxiety, depression) that occur within 3 months of an identifiable psychosocial stressor (eg, divorce, illness) lasting < 6 months once the stressor has ended.

If symptoms persist > 6 months after stressor ends, it is GAD. And symptoms dont meet the criteria for MDD. Treat with CBT/SSRIs.

questions.stem: A previously healthy 16-year-old girl comes to the physician because of a 4-day history of severe vaginal itching and a yellowish discharge. She is sexually active and uses condoms inconsistently. Pelvic examination shows a bubbly, yellowish vaginal discharge. Saline wet mount preparation of the discharge and a vaginal wall scraping show motile organisms and numerous leukocytes. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.explanation:
Trichomonas: You have to treat both partners because it is motile.

Clinical findings: thin, yellow-green, malodorous, frothy discharge and vaginal inflammation / itching.

Lab findings: pH >4.5 and motile trichomonads.

questions.stem: A 77-year-old woman has been having difficulty fastening buttons. She has weakness of the intrinsic muscles of the hands and loss of sensation in the little fingers. Which of the following is the most likely cause of these findings?

options.text: Chronic lunate subluxation with median nerve compression
Compression of the radial nerve in the spiral groove
Compression of the ulnar nerve in the carpal tunnel

questions.explanation:
Little finger = ulnar nerve.

C8-T1 are the roots of the ulnar nerve, which is a branch of the medial cord.
The ulnar nerve is not found in the carpal tunnel (the median nerve is). This trick probably got people.

Ulnar n. damage can lead to loss of wrist flexion and adduction, flexion of medial fingers, abduction and adduction of fingers (interossei), actions of medial 2 lumbrical muscles.
Loss of sensation over medial 1 1/2 fingers, including hypothenar eminence.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old man comes to the physician because of a persistent cough for the past 2 months. He has had a 5-kg (11-lb) weight loss during this period. He is a farmer and started itraconazole therapy 4 weeks ago for histoplasmosis acquired after contact with chicken coops. Current medications also include hydrochlorothiazide, enalapril, atenolol, omeprazole, and metoclopramide for hypertension and gastroesophageal reflux. He appears thin. Physical examination shows no other abnormalities. An interaction between itraconazole and which of the following drugs most likely accounts for the lack of effect of itraconazole?
questions.explanation:
Itraconazole requires the acidic environment of the stomach to be absorbed.
Omeprazole inhibits the H+/K+ pump of the stomach, thereby decreasing the acidity of the stomach.
So when the patient takes Omeprazole and Itraconazole together, Itraconazole won't be absorbed into the body. That's why it has no effect.

It's recommended to take medications at least 2 hours prior to taking an antacid.

This link says --https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3671798/
Omeprazole has actual adverse influences on the pharmacokinetics of medications such as diazepam, carbamazepine, clozapine, indinavir, nelfinavir, atazanavir, rilpivirine, methotrexate, tacrolimus, mycophenolate mofetil, clopidogrel, digoxin, itraconazole, posaconazole, and oral iron supplementation.

questions.stem: A strain of Escherichia coli produces a temperature-sensitive tryptophan synthase and therefore requires exogenously supplied tryptophan for growth at 42Â°C but not at 30Â°C. Which of the following mutations is most likely responsible for this phenotype?
questions.explanation:
Missense mutations involve a nucleotide substitution resulting in changed amino acids.
Sometimes the effects of missense mutations may be only apparent under certain environmental conditions;
such missense mutations are called conditional mutations.
Many missense mutations result in proteins that are still functional, at least to some degree.

Also, all the other answers would probably leave you with either a greatly altered or non-functional protein that would not work at any temperature.

questions.stem: A 16-year-old student has uncontrollable sleepiness, falling asleep several times a day while sitting in class. The slightest noise or touch is enough to awaken him. Which of the following most likely characterizes the onset of his sleep at night?

options.text: Direct transition from wakefulness to REM sleep
Direct transition from wakefulness to sleep stage 4
Gradual transition from wakefulness to sleep stage 1
Immediate transition from wakefulness to sleep stage 2

questions.explanation:
This is an interesting one. I like to remember it this way: in people with narcolepsy, all the "right kinds" of sleep are happening at all the "wrong times" of day.
During the day, when a power nap would typically throw you immediately into REM, this kid is only entering Stage 1 or 2 (lightest sleep = slightest noises jar him back to reality). At night, when he should peacefully drift into Stage 1, 2, and so on, he instead completely zonks out. Classic narcolepsy.

First Aid tells you -- "Sleep that starts with REM sleep, causing sleep paralysis."

From UpToDate: https://www.uptodate.com/contents/clinical-features-and-diagnosis-of-narcolepsy-in-adults
"Narcolepsy can be conceptualized as a disorder of sleep-wake control in which elements of sleep intrude into wakefulness and elements of wakefulness intrude into sleep."

questions.stem: A 30-year-old woman with multiple sclerosis comes to the physician because of a 2-week history of severe shooting pains in her right cheek. Each pain lasts less than 1 second. The pains sometimes occur spontaneously and sometimes are precipitated by a light touch to the right cheek. The most likely cause of this new finding is a plaque in which of the following locations?
questions.explanation:
This patient has pain in her right cheek due to the trigeminal nerve.
The pons has nerves 5-8, so the trigeminal would be affected here.

questions.stem: A 50-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his wife because of a 3-hour history of confusion and difficulty seeing. He says he is seeing flickering 'snowflake-like white spots' that interfere with his vision. He has a 3-year history of alcohol use disorder. His wife says he has been drinking a commercial product containing methanol. He appears anxious, confused, and incoherent. His temperature is 36.8Â°C (98.2Â°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 26/min, and blood pressure is 120/80 mm Hg. Physical examination shows dilated pupils and diminished pupillary reflex. Serum studies show a pH of 7.25 and an anion gap of 24 mEq/L (N=10â12). The most likely cause of this patient's visual symptoms is an excess of which of the following metabolites?
questions.explanation:
Methanol is toxic by two mechanisms:

First, methanol can be fatal due to its CNS depressant properties in the same manner as ethanol poisoning.

Second, in a process of toxication, it is metabolized to formic acid via formaldehyde in a process initiated by the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase in the liver. Methanol is converted to formaldehyde via alcohol dehydrogenase (ADH) and formaldehyde is converted to formic acid (formate) via aldehyde dehydrogenase (ALDH).

Formate is toxic because it inhibits mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase, causing hypoxia at the cellular level, and metabolic acidosis, among a variety of other metabolic disturbances.

questions.stem: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. She has a family history of skin cancer and rigorously avoids exposure to the sun. Her dietary intake of vitamin D meets current recommendations. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a decreased 25-hydroxycholecalciferol concentration. Decreased production of which of the following precursors in skin is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Notice, the stem says "precursors in the skin"

D3 (cholecalciferol) from exposure of skin (stratum basale) to sun, ingestion of fish, milk, plants.

D2 (ergocalciferol) from ingestion of plants, fungi, yeasts.

Both converted to 25-OH D3 (storage form) in liver and to the active form 1,25-(OH)2 D3 (calcitriol) in kidney.

questions.stem: A 45-year-old man has fever, chills, dysuria, and a tender, enlarged prostate. Which of the following is the most likely causal organism?
questions.explanation:
Prostatitis is characterized by dysuria, frequency, urgency, low back pain. Warm, tender, enlarged prostate.

Acute bacterial prostatitisâin people >35 it is most commonly E. coli.
In people <35 it can be Chlamydia or Neisseria.

questions.stem: An 8-year-old boy is evaluated for ventricular systolic overload. The standard-lead ECG shows severe left axis deviation of the main QRS vector (upward in lead I and downward in lead II). Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Walk through the pathological choices logically.
Coarctation of the aorta leads to increased LV overload causing LV hypertrophy and a L axis deviation.
Mitral stenosis is unlikely in an 8 year old.
Pulmonary valve stenosis would not cause LV systolic overload, but it would cause RV hypertrophy.
RV hypertrophy, however, would also not cause LV systolic overload.
Nor would RA hypertrophy, which barely occurs.

questions.stem: A 48-year-old man comes to the physician for a routine examination. He has a 6-month history of angina. His mother died at the age of 56 years of coronary artery disease. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show a total cholesterol concentration of 450 mg/dL; LDL-cholesterol concentration is increased, and HDL-cholesterol and triglyceride concentrations are within the reference range. Following angiography and angioplasty of his circumflex coronary artery, treatment with a statin is begun. Statins are most likely to decrease this patient's serum cholesterol concentration by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.explanation:
By inhibiting HMG-CoA reductase, we no longer make more mevalonate, a cholesterol precursor.
So we run out of cholesterol and our liver upregulates LDL receptors to take back more.

Remember that HMG-CoA reductase is for cholesterol synthesis.

questions.stem: During an experiment, an investigator isolates an abnormal elastin with unusual instability from the connective tissue of mice. Analysis of the elastin shows a decreased number of desmosine cross-links. Upon amino acid analysis, the concentration of which of the following amino acids in the abnormal protein would be most likely different when compared with normal elastin?

explanationImage.alt: Elastin structure diagram showing desmosine cross-links

questions.explanation: Lysine is used in elastin and collagen cross linking; it is cross linked by lysyl oxidase to make collagen fibers.

questions.info: A 35-year-old woman with newly diagnosed hypertension comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Her blood pressure today is 153/106 mm Hg in the right upper extremity and 156/104 mm Hg in the left upper extremity. A bruit is heard just lateral to the umbilicus on the right side of the abdomen. Laboratory studies show:

infoImages.alt: Laboratory values showing serum electrolytes, glucose, creatinine and urine studies

questions.stem: Which of the following additional diagnostic tests is most appropriate to establish the cause of this patient's hypertension?

options.text: Measurement of urine free cortisol concentration
CT scan of the adrenal glands
MR angiography of the renal arteries

questions.explanation:
Renovascular disease is the most common cause of 2Â° HTN in adults.
Can be due to ischemia from renal stenosis or microvascular disease.
Can hear renal bruits lateral to umbilicus.

Main causes of renal artery stenosis:
Atherosclerotic plaquesâproximal 1/3rd of renal artery, usually in older males, smokers.
Fibromuscular dysplasiaâdistal 2/3rd of renal artery or segmental branches, in middle-aged females.

Stenosis decreases blood flow to glomerulus.
Juxtaglomerular apparatus (JGA) responds by secreting renin, which converts angiotensinogen to angiotensin I.
Angiotensin I is converted to angiotensin II (ATII) by angiotensin converting enzyme (ACEâin lungs).
ATII raises blood pressure by (1) contracting arteriolar smooth muscle, increasing total peripheral resistance and (2) promoting adrenal release of aldosterone, which increases reabsorption of sodium (where Na+ goes H2O will follow) in the distal convoluted tubule (expanding plasma volume).
Can lead to hypokalemia (seen in the labs for this question).
Leads to HTN with increased plasma renin and unilateral atrophy (due to low blood flow) of the affected kidney; neither feature is seen in primary hypertension.

questions.stem: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department because of a 4-day history of constant headache and vomiting following mild exercise. Today, she developed right-sided weakness and slurred speech. She has no history of major medical illness and takes no medications. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows right-sided hemiparesis. Serum studies show increased concentrations of pyruvate and lactate. Immunohistochemical staining of a muscle biopsy specimen shows a deficiency of NADH dehydrogenase activity. A pedigree is shown; the patient is indicated by the arrow. Which of the following is the most likely mode of inheritance of the disorder in this patient?
questions.explanation:
We cannot see the pedigree here sadly, and it had an unaffected male born to an affected mother, which really threw off many people and that is messed up.

Regardless, they clearly describe MELAS here and the NADH dehydrogenase is basically complex 1 of the mitochondria ETSystem.

questions.stem: A 10-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her mother for a well-child examination. She has not yet had a menstrual period. She is at the 50th percentile for height and weight. Physical examination shows absence of breast bud development and no pubic or axillary hair. The mother asks how she will know when her daughter begins puberty. It is most appropriate for the physician to tell the mother that the first objective sign of puberty will be which of the following?
questions.explanation: The same page explicitly explains that the earliest detectable secondary sexual characteristic is breast bud development in girls, testicular enlargement in boys.

questions.stem: A 65-year-old woman who has a 25-year history of chronic alcoholism is brought to the emergency department because she is vomiting blood. She eats little more than an occasional sandwich. Examination of the legs shows perifollicular hyperkeratosis and hemorrhage. Abnormally decreased function of which of the following metabolic pathways is most likely in this patient?
questions.explanation: Page 69 discusses Vitamin C deficiency. She has a vitamin C deficiency. Scurvy features swollen gums, easy bruising, petechiae, perifollicular and subperiosteal hemorrhages.

questions.stem: A 33-year-old woman with HIV infection is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after she had a generalized tonic-clonic seizure. She also has a 2-month history of daily headaches. Physical examination shows no signs of meningismus. Muscle strength is 3/5 in the left upper extremity and 5/5 in the right upper extremity. Serologic studies show a positive IgG antibody titer to Toxoplasma gondii. Treatment with pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine is initiated. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this mass?
questions.explanation: Page 462 discusses PCNSL. This is a primary central nervous system lymphoma. Most commonly associated with HIV/AIDS; pathogenesis involves EBV infection. Needs to be distinguished from toxoplasmosis via CSF analysis or other lab tests.
